Teslas net income is down 32 yy through the first three quarters of the year. Not good. Their original guidance was 50 CAGR from 2020 2030. They were above 50 through 2023. Through 2024, their CAGR looks like itll be dropping to around 38. If they maintain a similar unit sales volume in 2025, itll drop to 30. Not good. Tesla has a forward PE of over 72 right now, which will be even higher tomorrow. Other OEMs, who have performed far better than Tesla recently, are sitting around forward PEs of 57. Teslas valuation heavily relies on the idea of constant future growth. Their robotaxi event was generally scoffed at. Not good. It was fairly expected theyd beat estimates, and given how shit the stock has been lately, that often leads to a short term pump. I could see a 61.8 retracement by the end of the month from wherever its high is over the next 12 days probably right around 240, dropping to 222. Then I imagine itll pop back up to a lower high around 250255. Then, its likely all down from there, likely back down to around the 160175 area by beginning of next year... lining up with quarterly sales figures which I dont expect to be spectacular. Maybe it beats last year, but that isnt saying much when they were previously claiming a 50 CAGR. Why this stock is worth so much more than other auto OEMs is probably a question a lot of major investors are asking themselves. A lot of them were betting on autonomous taxis... but Musk can only claim its 12 years away for so long before they eventually start to wise up. 10 years... hes been claiming that every year for 10 years straight now The stocks a dog, Meme investors just dont know it yet. Its been in a long term downward trend, no doubt supported by a core of buy and hold forever insiders and cultists, and of course SP index funds that will only sell if everyone else does. Regulatory credits are 100 income 100 corporate profit. Comparing the first 3 quarters of the year, their regulatory income is approximately 700 million higher than the previous highest year. Theyve pulled in about 1.7 1.8 billion in regulatory income in each of the last two years. Theyre on course to pull in 2.5 billion in regulatory income in 2024. Its a pretty massive chunk of their total net income for having to do absolutely nothing to get it save sell the cars they were going to sell anyways. Their net income through the first 3 quarters is 4.807 billion, versus 7.069 billion last year, or 32 lower yy. Remove the 700 million extra in regulatory credits yy, and it would have been closer to 4.1 billion or a 42 drop in income yy on their actual product sales. Theyre on course to just about match their total unit vehicle sales yy theyre still a bit behind last year through Q3. The problem is that their long term guidance which helped lead to the run up overvaluation in the stock price is 50 CAGR between 2020 and 2030. They rescinded that guidance in Q3 23 because they dont believe its possible anymore. To stay even with the 50 CAGR in 2024, theyd have need to sell over 2.5 million vehicles, but theyre on course to sell about 1.8 million. 2025 could see little if any sales growth versus 20232024. However, to maintain the 50 CAGR in 2025, theyd have to hit 3.8 million vehicle sales. Starting to see the problem? Their forward PE is based on crazy growth guidance, which even Tesla has admitted they cant hit, yet the stock is still trading at a forward PE of over 80. Most of the major OEMs across the world trade a forward PE of between 5 and 7. Teslas sales arent growing, their revenue isnt growing, and their income isnt growing, which means their PE is based on nothing more than a hope and a dream. Just to repeat from my last comment, and add a bit more info, regulatory credit isnt simple revenue... its 100 net income... 100 profits. 739 million is 33.6 of Q3s net income. Keep in mind, a massive chunk of their remaining net income comes from government subsidies. In the US for example, theyre still seeing 7500 federal tax credits on a large percentage of their total sales which allows them to maintain higher MSRPs, translating into higher profit margins. Most of their sales are in states with state EV tax credits as well, often in the 15002500 range. Some as high as 5000. Their energy sales are even more subsidized than their car sales. The federal government subsidizes something like 30 of the overall cost of a solar panel home battery storage installation. States with the highest rooftop solar adoption rates often have additional incentives on top. Overall, it can reach up to 50. Im not sure on their grid scale power storage, but Im guessing the subsidies andor the amount theyre charging the government, which often has mandates written into law to have storage installed, are lucrative. Like 2023... if Tesla were to exclude regulatory credit income and government subsidies from their income, theyd likely be reporting a loss for 2024. I guess this doesnt technically matter unless there were a risk that the subsidies were going to disappear in short order.. which theres no sign of. Some headwinds for Q4 Theyve removed their lowest priced trim model 3 near the end of Q3, which had the imported Chinese LFP battery. That could hit their overall sales numbers in Q4. It also means theyre not going to sell cars with the significantly cheaper LFP packs, which likely generated some decent profit margins. These units didnt qualify for the full tax credit on sales although I do believe they still qualified on leases, which Tesla would have had to roll into the lease price. Not sure if they did or didnt do that. They significantly cut the price of the Cybertruck and still dont seem to have a backlog after the price cut per their estimated delivery dates on their site. Theyve significantly cut the prices on their inventory vehicles. Model 3s Ive seen have up to 3k discounts applied. Model Y has as much as 4k discounts applied. Model Y accounts for the majority of their sales. That said, they were also aggressively discounting inventory vehicles last year in Q4. Theyre offering 0 financing offers which I believe is new this year. While this wont impact their unit sales, it will mean additional losses of up to 5k per vehicle over the course of the loan that they otherwise would have made on interest. I do expect Tesla to break their sales numbers from last year, if only because theyre so deeply discounting their vehicles. However, I expect their revenue and net income to be down in Q4 yy as a result of their deep discounting.

I used to work for a guy at a global logistics company. We were tasked with building something that had never been built before, using Machine LearningTM. The idea is simple. Cradle to grave assessments dont cover things like mining. Ive been in the EV community and been researching this topic for a very very very long time, bud. There are certainly unknowns that are never mentioned or covered, which is why I mention those things out in my comments. For example, I didnt say increased cost of battery production. I specifically noted the high front loading of high emissions. Why did I mention this? The planet can only sequester so much carbon over a given period. What happens if we significantly increase the amount of carbon we produce in a given year on account of a manufacturing process that spikes the levels of emissions? What are the impacts to the environment? Does it result in more ocean acidification, because the CO2 is sucked up by the oceans instead of the forests? Thus leading to devastation of coral reefs and oceanic plant life, and styming the Oceans ability to sequester more carbon? Again, not something covered in cradle to grave assessments.. Sure, power grids are changing... slowly... and will continue to do so over time. That doesnt mean there arent significantly better solutions to the environmental problem than simply MOAR CARS!. Were to the point where every bit of CO2 we inject into the atmosphere will likely require more energy and time to suck back out of the atmosphere in the future with CO2 sequestration processes. IMO, the best solution is to not emit in the first place. We, humans, need to drastically reduce our carbon footprints in a very short period of time. BEVs help, never said they dont. Dollar for impact... theyre about the slowest solution for reducing global emissions.

No disrespect but, I think its you who doesnt understand the technology. Im going to quote one of their engineers Chad Wahlquist explaining why you need an Ontology core moat to scale LLMs within your business context As we scale stochastic unpredictable LLMs to power more dynamic and useful workflows, we enter a new domain of decisions and actions. You now need humans and AI to work together as a team, with more controls over whowhatwhenwherewhy actions can be taken. It is no longer a clear line between humans or systems. The Ontology acts as the substrate for simulating, orchestrating, controlling, and reviewing decisions in a world where HumansAI work together. LLMs bring new reasoning capabilities, which is amazing but also dangerous see all the public oops moments already from just deploying an LLM. True value is created when the loop is closed, the action is taken, and the Ontology provides the scalable framework to do so. Your business is a system of systems that is getting more complex by the day. You cannot merely shoehorn an LLM into the mix and expect your existing endtoend architecture to support quality decisionmaking with HumansAI. The Ontology acts as the fabric across your business, orchestrating the data, logic, actions and security of your operations, systems, and people to power entirely new capabilities that HumanAI teaming can bring. Visual The Ontology allows you to move past the window dressing that is Copilot and others like it because it enables the LLM to both understand your business logic and write back to your core applications. What does this look like in the real world? Shyam Sankar CTO recently went on CNBC and talked about how one of their large US insurance clients automated all of their underwriting using 78 AI agents. A process that use to take 2 weeks now takes 3 hours. If all of your competitors take 2 weeks to price risk, and you take 3 hours, its going to be a fundamental dislocation of the market. I have many more examples if you are interested with sources. Disclosure Palantir is 20 of my holdings

Of course their employees wont speak ill about their product offerings, and will bring up AI since thats what everybody has been talking about for the last couple of years. But the fact is LLMs are marketed as some AI that can reason while it cant doesnt help that _reasoning_ has a very specific meaning in the field, which obviously gets lost in marketing talk. Now were well into the second year of everybody trying to fit LLMs into any business application while struggling to solve the hallucination problem, which is not a problem to be solved but rather a technological feature that wont go away. You dump a load of data and expect that a statistical model with a random seed will generate consistent output. Then you waste more time applying optimization techniques that will never solve that problem fully. LLMs are great for controlled translation original propose and text reformulation and summarization which is tangential to translation. They might be good at software code conversion too also a translation application, but not so much at generating new code reliably though. They cant generate text about subject matters that werent incorporated into their training. They cant talk about anything that hasnt been spoken yet. Essentially a parrot as far as new content generation is concerned. Nobody has come up any killer application for LLMs so far. Dont get me wrong, I think LLM tech is great and proven to be here to stay, but it is currently at the center of a speculative bubble. It will be interesting to see what happens once the bubble bursts.

My point was they dont have any technological moat or differentiating features. And yes, AIP certainly didnt exist 10 years ago, in fact engineering leadership at Palantir was notoriously antiML back then although theyre doing a great job chasing the trend now. I dont find build.palantir.com to be very technologically impressive, its a set of very simple tools that already exist in OSS today and has been integrated in by major cloud providers. What have you built using this that wouldnt be more scalable, robust and cost effective than using Sagemaker, DBX or even the flaming garbage pile that is GCP? What is a specific problem or domain where Palantir is best in class? Relying on a companies marketing material as your source of truth is a dangerous way to reaffirm preexisting beliefs. As is following influencers who unapologetically shill stocks and cherrypick data to fit their narrative and boost engagement from their target audience by telling you what you want to hear. OP is correct that most technical users of Palantir software think its overpriced and lacking differentiating features. That doesnt mean the stock wont go up further, or that the product wont improve, but its something you should try to be objective about when researching.

They have a great sales and marketing team. No technology moat. etc. CRWD was around 140 at that point. Really glad I didnt listen to him.

So they are making the old age mistake of thinking the tech will solve all their problems, but it wont. If they have bad people they need better people. Thats why Palantir will never take off in the private sector, because they have better engineers who realise they dont need to overpay for a platform when they can get something very similar that requires a bit more configuration at a fraction of the cost. As for the government customers, they wont realise the value because you still need people who understand the tech for that.

I think the key word here is mitigation, and whether the results are acceptable for the task at hand. Maybe if youre doing analysis over subjective data, e.g. flagging content for potential fraud or collusion, that might be okay. Fully automating a workflow with that output is risky, however, given that the dataset used in training might contain biases and that the LLM could still come up with wild results, requiring human intervention. As I said, LLMs are great, but its not the killer tech the Sam Altmans out there want us to believe it is. I dont think it will replace call center people, for example, or software devs, or writers and artists. It might replace Google Search and other web search engines. Maybe it will be good for fraud detection, and in subjective data analysis, like in flagging content for human review. Thing is, when this bubble bursts, well come to know which players managed to get some usable products out there, but even then, its possible that everyone will get burned.

The insurance for the waste is one of the biggest prohibitions to nuclear waste. It essentially needs to be guaranteed forever, this results in the only ones willing to take the risk being states and countries.

It is not 75000 years to store waste. Low and intermediate level waste is stored for 30 years in cooldown pools before being buried is ceramic pucks, and hight level waste is stored for 50 years before being buried. High level waste loses 99.9 of its reactivity in 40 years. The worst high level waste is back to background level within 100010000 years. The Navy has stored all of its waste generated over the last 60 years of nuclear power in a single spent copper mine. 95 of waste is low level. 0.2 is high level, with intermediate making up the difference. 30 percent of all used fuel is reprocessed for reuse in reactors and a small percentage is refined for medical use. As for the cost. Long term storage for is estimated 10 of the total cost of the reactors lifetime expense, and is required by the government to be set aside to cover all costs.

Nuclear waste is an extremely over exagerated problem. The entirety of highly dangerous nuclear waste produced in France from the past 40 years fits into a single cube with sides measuring 15 meters. And Its the most nuclearized country in the world, and the total amount of carbon free energy produced for so little waste is absolutely outstanding.

Fat cats just didnt have the time to get the fuel so we were told solar and other bullshit is the way. Wut? Nuke was killed by NIMBYism. The fear of another Chernobyl, TMI, etc... forced the industry to be regulated to the point that for most companies it wasnt financially viable. The company I work for used to own Talen energy mentioned in this article the reason it was sold off is because it was just dead weight back then. Perfect example...at the Susquehanna plant mentioned, we had to keep two fleets of excavators on hand in case of a meltdown and pay for upkeep, maintenance, etc... It was literally redundancy for a black swan event, wild. This is the reason that Exelon has basically been the name in the game in nuke generation in the US. My old boss used to head up exelons nuke operations the only way they were able to make it profitable was through acquisition and absolutely ruthless standardization...they acquired a new plant and would implement the playbook...execsemployees who pushed back were gone. Same service intervals, same vendors for IT systems, same schemes, same excavator, same everything across the entire fleet. My company, as many others have long said nuke is the answer...with reasonable regulation. SMR and the involvement of big tech is bringing that conversation to the forefront. Nuke and nuke adjacent industries like utilities are great play at the moment. Same with NG, but thats a whole other discussion.

Even if you have a bunch of very safe drivers on the road, the more very safe drivers you have on the road the greater the odds that one of those very safe drivers will get into an accident, it happens every day because theres millions of them on the road. That above paragraph isnt fear mongering about nuclear energy, its statistical odds.

Your fallacy is in attributing the causes of previous nuclear incidents all to operator error. Humans make mistakes, of course, and Chernobyl management was definitely negligent and reckless. However, what made Chernobyl a disaster was shoddy reactor design that wouldve never been possible in the West. I mean, hitting the shutdown reactor button is what caused the Chernobyl reactors to explode! Same goes to Fukushima with its backup generator design and way too tiny tsunami seawalls. Its not just the Wests operational practices that have made nuclear energy so safe here. Its that reactor facilities have been designed with passive safety in mind to prevent operator error from ever causing a disaster, and the next generation nuclear technology takes that to another level. Its like saying cars in the 50s were so dangerous because even minor accidents could kill or cause severe injury, so people just shouldnt drive. Sure, operators need to improve, but the cars themselves could get a whole lot safer, and they have!

when the consequences of just one mistake at a nuclear plant could be catastrophic. replies.text: Kind of disagree. The consumer is sick of the Starbucks ripoff. Theyre looking for value, not sweet drinks that cost as much as a meal. Id been skeptical that just tweaks could fix that. I do believe making some big and fundamental and newsgenerating changes could fix Starbucks business. I also believe the small tweaks wont do anything. Seeing that 4 point letter from Niccol screams tweaks not true fundamental change. Its as much BS corpospeak as what Laxman was putting out. Empower the barista. Please. Ive read the employeedominated sub, and the theme is theyre sick of being worked to death and it sounds like many dont even like the customers. Understand the market isnt exactly a forensic fix for China. Customers tired of being ripped off dont need to be told the Starbucks story. The name on cups gag is played out. Making Starbucks a community coffeehouse isnt really what consumers want, and isnt necessarily good for the business. They want better value and they want to get in and out quickly. The 25 pop was the market assuming Niccol could make the inandout quickly thing, and the perceived value thing happen. This letter sounds like he doesnt even understand the problem. And the market annointing him as universal problem solving saint may be misguided. Yes, CMG stock had incredible growth and the brand became widely loved... for the first half of his tenure. But the second half is not as pretty. When problems started to appear, he seemed incapable of identifying and addressing them proactively. Chipotle is now widely perceived as being a ripoff and too bland. Bad portion sizes. Skimping on ingredients and quality. He seemed paralyzed and clueless about that. His last big public appearance before abandoning the ship was him goofily claiming the portions were consistent, as big as your head, and that if you ever felt you werent getting value, you should personally try to shame the worker into topping up your plate. Thats out of touch, not problem solving. So a perhaps more sober assessment of Niccol is that he was present while CMG rode the advantage of the stock being pummeled from killing customers with unsafe food, and then when the time came to actually solve problems, he couldnt recognize them let alone solve them. And now hes the one walking into a problemfest at Starbucks. I took my 24 gains and am waiting to see what happens. If I were given that job, instead of issuing that bad, pithy letter, heres what Id do acknowledge the deep problems which are a consumer no longer willing to pay luxury price for sugary milkshakes, employees placed in unfulfilling situations, operational inability to have quick, high volume output. fixes would be in the form of Big Bang changes and candid humility. Look to the dominos model where they apologized and acknowledged cardboard level pizza. Fix the bad, burnt coffee taste perception. look also to McDonalds who knows you have to keep volume going even when consumers are strapped and sick of you, and they do that with inarguably value through literal value menus. Id have some newsgenerating low priced options as a form of Starbucks value menu look also to McDonalds who figured out how to massively pump out drive through where your order is prepared in the time it takes between ordering and paying and pickup window, and then making that parallel with two or more lanes. Id overhaul the operations substantially. Despite what coffeehouse baristas think, efficient machines can make most of a drink just fine. Weve all had delicious mass produced smoothies, Nespressos, etc. Id lean heavy on such automation and preparation to massively ramp up how much and how quickly a location can pump out the drinks, and let the baristas be more of a presentation element. Let them use their time and personalities with the customers instead of tamping away and washing seives in the back. Yes, Id be fine with a scenario where premade or machine made drinks are pumped out under a counter and a charming baritas focus on pretending they made it and making the customer feel happy and that theyve been served quickly. Make it globally known that the long lineups are over and that you can get a plain coffee for 3 from the value menu. this would address both the biggest consumer deterrents plus make life liveable for the baristas. it turns Starbucks back into a perceived affordable treat, an attainable piece of luxury at a good price. Theres more, but you get the point. Sure, theres a halo on Niccol, and a whole ecosystem of Wall Street and financial news media that is invested in claiming Starbucks is great regardless of the truth. But in terms of actual transformational change, my plan seems to have more substance than tell the Starbucks story

Ill go back to Starbucks if they drop prices by 50 and put tables back in their shops. I havent been in years because its overpriced and not even good coffee. Plus no one meets at Starbucks anymore. Its that simple.

TradingView has an awesome Calendar section that you can filter based on countries or various other indicators, and theyll show a variety of reports on each day like oil rig count, unemployment, Powell speaking, etc. Theres also an app called Quartr that Ill fallen in love with. Displays all Quarterly earnings reports for all publicly traded companies each day, or you can filter based on the companies you follow. They even will link you directly to the press conference as its happening.l Edit its actually called the Calendar section

The relevant ones are nonfarm payroll, initial jobless claims, JOLTS, GDP, CPI, PPI, retail sales, PCE, ISM manufacturing, ISM nonmanufacturing, FOMC. Fed governors speaking calendar. Havent found a Fed presidents speaking calendar yet. Those are about it. Theres a twitter account FinancialJuice that tweets real time econfinance news. Maybe theres a better twitter account out there, but thats the one I follow.
I dont invest in companies that Im not comfortable holding onto if the exchange was closed for years.
Time. Set your goal for 1 to 2 quarters out or longer and the iOS and downs from news events dont matter
You dont, you invest in diversified funds to avoid his issue, even then it can still be an issue.
Number always go up, we promise
If I see orders from my dom drop off and Im in a trade, Ill bail if I dont know the reason. Ive been caught on the wrong side of that before.

You have three choices 1. Track the event calendar. None of these reports are secret, the release dates arent surprises. 2. Have an investment strategy that is more that basic attempts at day trading based on having a solid thesis about the companies you are investing in. Then these reports dont matter. 3. Invest in diversified funds and then none of this noise matters and youll probably do better than the people who follow the first 2.

An alternative to the calendar suggestion Get in the habit of always setting a stop loss or trailing stop loss or both order immediately some brokers allow you to buy and then set a sell order in the same execution. The larger the loss youre willing to accept, the larger your trail value should be. If youre using a trailing stop loss, look at the daily trading history of the stock be sure to look at days that are just bad days for the stock market generally. Set your trailing stop loss to be more than the max loss you could expect to see in a single day, but less than a free fall drop that could happen after bad news. 10 is a good starting point. On a final note, I am much tighter with my trail amounts in my tax advantaged IRA accounts, because I dont give a shit if the sell order triggers. I can just buy the stock the next day at a discount and not have to worry about long vs short cap gains. It is exceedingly rare that a stock could drop 10 and trigger a stop loss and then jump back positive in the same day. If it hits 10 in one day chances are it will go even lower before it goes back up.
Mr. Market is an attention whore. He likes to make noise and dance around showing report after report. Be the casino and invest in index funds.

Obviously js google it but if youre not an active manager or a day trader dont even worry about the market reactions in the short term. It always overreacts initially then self corrects so dont stress keeping up with every little economic report. Most of it is lagging anyway.
If you have a decent broker, theyll have an economic calendar somewhere on their site. You dont need a separate service.

replies.text: There are narrow global large cap company ETFs like iShares Dow Jones Global Titans 50 UCITS ETF. It has outperformed MSCI World developed world and SP 500 in the past 5 years. So its a probably good idea and you can gauge the performance that you can expect to have. This ETF is domiciled in Germany, but Im sure there are similar ones.

I have a desire to diversify outside of America but have always been disappointed in the gains of international ETFs compared to US based ones. Maybe because its early, but Im not getting why now if youve always been disappointed. Youre buying just the largest caps internationally, but given the nature of the names you mentioned, one or more were probably a part of the international ETFs you were disappointed in. People have talked up a bounce in international names given relative valuations for years, but aside from specific stories MELI, to use an example, EMinternational DMs have largely underperformed US for a long time including at the large cap level. I think there are great specific stories in Europe, Asia, Latin America and own some of them a lot of them smallmid caps but I have no interest in owning international fundsindexes broadly. Say you have 10k to invest, you would buy 4400 of Saudi Aramco, 2030 of Taiwan Semiconductors, 1310 of Novo Nordisk, 1290 of Tencent 1290, and 970 of Louie Vuitton It feels like buying the largest companies for the sake of buying the largest companies. Which could wind up working out fine, but I just think if youre buying an individual company, its good to consider why this specificallyis this a good time to buyetc. Looks like one issure is many of these companies are listed on the Shanghai Stock Exchange, which I cant buy as a Canadian Not sure if Canadians can buy US ADRs somehow, or GDRs in other countries that have decent enough volumeliquidity. also is there a way to backtest this strategy You can backtest a portfolio to a limited degree at but I dont know of a place you can backtest a broader strategy.

Nvidia is participating in round tripping too. Acquire stake in AI startup contingent on them buying Nvidia products, those sales get recorded as revenue for nvidia, and the cash they spend on acquisition also shows on balance sheet. Net effect shows net growth and profit, when in reality all they did is give cash to a company to buy their own products. The problem is after a few years, as the GPUs get depreciated, that gets passed on as an equity method lossor goodwill impairment in the case of full acquisitions and begins to show on Nvidias earnings. But Nvidia can hide this in the short term by growing the rate that they close new deals. Ultimately, it will depend on the success of these AI startups. If they actually become profitable and produce good return on invested capitalROIC, then these companies doing round tripping could perform well. But if they fail, then big tech will take a hit too. Secondly, big tech companies are developing their own AI chips now so that they dont have to keep paying the insane markups on Nvidia chips, which are sold at double digit multiples of their production costs. Id say every venture has potential for predictable negative consequences. More benevolent companies actively mitigate for the consequences and externalities of their actions. Sometimes it helps the bottom line in the long run, sometimes it doesnt. Some companies dont try to push legislation which helps the bottom line at the expense of everyone else. That said, companies pushing stronger standards which superficially help consumers are often doing it because they are structured better to benefit from those standards than their competitors e.g. legal compliance PR groups that enjoy economies of scale. The bar is pretty low in many industries, but retailers like Costco have a better than average reputation for treating workers decently and for providing decent valuequality to customers, for instance. Its impossible to please everyone, but If a company is performing decently, gets some positive press, has good brand loyalty, and doesnt get consistently complained about, and isnt causing willful or negligent harms, thats a pretty good reputation on the whole, IMO.

replies.text: You dont get the full 3k back in tax refunds. You only get a 3k deduction in taxable income which means if your income was 100k for the year, assuming you have the full 3k capital loss, you will be taxed as if your income was 97k for the year.

You can fully deduct losses against capital gains. If you have 1M in losses and 1M in gains your net capital gains is 0 and you pay zero capital gains taxes. If you have losses _above_ your capital gains, you can negate up to 3k a year from your regular income.
you only get a tax refund if you over pay taxes vs your income

The 3000 limit applies to excess losses over your other income. In other words, if you have 100k income and 105k losses, you can only deduct 103k losses and the remaining 2k carries over to next year.

Realizing a net capital loss of 3000 reduces your taxable income by that much. The amount of tax you owe is then calculated based on that amount of income. There is no refund or credit involved. Its simply an income change.
Im sure many well educated people on here that can help, but i would call a tax professional as some do free consulatations. Better to hear it from the horses mouth kinda deal

You dont get a refund for capital losses. And you dont get to write off capital losses against other income. Capital losses can only be used against capital gains. If you have 0 capital gains for this year, you get to carry the capital losses over to be used against capital gains in future years.

Do you itemize your losses and deductions, or do you usually take the federal standard deduction? That 3,000 can be a deduction but unless you have more than 12,000 total in deductions on your taxes overall it probably wont be worth it
Yes its a reduction in income deduction not a tax credit. So the benefit depends on your tax bracket. The lower tax bracket the less benefit.
That refund would be dope though
Does the brokerage automatically figure in losses on the tax document? Or is that something the traderinvestor needs to keep track of?
If its more can you carry them over to next year?
This sounds most plausible......... a lot of people forget that their main source of capital gain is their main employer not trading
And that is only a factor for those who deduct more than the standard minimum, which is around 12K
Thats not correct. Up to 3k of realized loses can be used to deduct from your income.
This is false. Capital losses are deducted from your Adjusted Gross Income regardless of whether you itemize or not. See IRC 1211b.
How so? Your refund would be way less than your capital loss.

They usually give you a summary at the end and you can figure out tax loss from that when you file taxes. Like when I use TurboTax or FreeTaxUSA I put in my cost basis and sales numbers in the required tax form and it will show a negative capital gain which is a net loss. If you file using the same service it should pull information from previous years for a carry over loss as well.
Brokerage should calculate your total long term and short term lossesgains.

Yes, if you have losses over your capital gains, you negate 3k a year from regular income and carry the rest over into the next year where you would repeat the procedure net against gains, then 3k against income, then carry over.
Yes. Ive lost 90k one year, then carried it over to the next. Paid 0 tax on my capital gains the following year.

No. The guy you commented to said income but they meant capital gains. You can not claim 100,000 capital losses when making 100,000 from your employer, and pay no taxes. You get to deduct 3k of the capital losses from your wages. Then still pay on the 100k3k 97,000 from your employer, 3k gets deducted from your capital losses, and the other 97 capital losses carry over to the next year. The only thing that can eliminate more than 3k the next year is if you made profit in capital gains and then you deduct it pretend its 20 and 3 more against wages from the 97 to carryover 97203 74 to the following year. Edit Source carried over losses for the last 11 years and finally emptied my carryover this past April 15th. I can sell off a couple bags just like OP to extend my not paying for another year or so, but then its gonna hurt.

Capital gains and losses are not related to whether one itemizes deductions or chooses the standard deduction. They are purely part of ones calculated gross income. Deductions are factored in after that, producing ones taxable income.
My mistake, I was misinformed
How would a 3k refund be less than a 3k loss?
Thats neat. Pretty much free money

thanks for the clear up, i have 12k to make back this year fuck. But say if you make gains, do you have to pay IRS every quarter by the deadline? But the deadlines dont overlap to quarter ends properly so it seems like you need to project your 68 weeks of income and pay that in advance or how does it work when you profit
I stand corrected

Because you dont get 3k refunded. You get refunded as if you made 3k less than you did. Assuming a tax rate of 20 because Im lazy and not looking at any specific tax bracket, thats a refund of 600 in federal taxes.

Not sure SEC and broker would agree its free but yeah they were happy. Its why everyone is happy when they get to ring the opening bell everyday... they always make money. 90k in profits could mean millions in trading transactions where they charge per sell. The SEC fee is based on the total dollar amount of securities sold, so larger trades will incur a higher fee. For example, if you sell 10,000 worth of stock, you will pay a fee of 0.051 0.0000051 x 10,000. If you sell 1 million worth of stock, you will pay a fee of 5.10.
Well.. not really. I was 90k. Next year I broke even, so a net of 0. I spent 2 years of stock trading to make a grand total of 0.

From how the tax code reads, if you recognize 3k in capital loses you get a 3k deduction from your AGI. Not a 3k minus taxes deduction to your AGI. So I was saying it was a direct credit of 3k instead of a deduction, that would be dope. To not have to worry about up to 3k of your losses since youd get them back at tax time.
After a year you forget that money existed. You make it back and dont have to pay taxes on it.

The SEC and your broker are happy . You paid thousands to the SEC allowing capital to flow and continue. Are you saying in your second year you made 90k profit from trading and therefore paid 0 in taxes because of previous year losses of 90k? Two years of stock trading is a PHD from top business school.

Essentially all my understanding of it comes from my accounting textbook, and the way the book explained it made me immediately think this could put a lot of people out of business specifically all of the middlemen that are used for transfers. Cause when a business sends a transfer of right now it has to go through 2, 3, 4, or more people to get to its destination, and it seems incredibly inefficient and a waste of money for everyone but the middlemen because all theyre doing is confirming, recording, and sending it on.

Upon reflection, what they might be trying to get out is changing direct debit dates, which I have to say is an absolute faff. Most organisations only have particular dates you can have them on for example my council tax has to be on something like the 10th, 18th, or 28th of every month and some organisations dont let you change it at all so its purely based on when you signed up. If this solves that problem it would be hugely helpful for people like me who likes having everything come out on payday.

I cant really imagine not using a credit card just for security reasons, the rewards are just a bonus.

MA is often middle men, disruptors, or smaller competitors being bought out by the big players. IIRC V and MC have absorbed quite a few smaller companies over the years. Where the middle man is providing a service that you may not be able to replicate inhouse, you leave it alone.

As the other guy said, Blockchain is a known tech and all banks have teams working on finding use cases for it The fact that it still hasnt materialised in any meaningful way says a lot Also, the middlemen are often forced by AML KYC laws. It would be a lot faster and cheaper if there werent any controls. Money launderers and terrorists would love it too

The grey market?

Grey market goods are goods sold outside the authorized distribution channels by entities which may have no relationship with the producer of the goods. This form of parallel import frequently occurs when the price of an item is significantly higher in one country than another. It may not be illegal in the country thats manufacturing it but it is in the distribution country.

Yes unregulated distribution of a coldchain reliant injectable longterm acting peptide drug is most definitely a safe and trustworthy way to lose weight. Id honestly rather heroin. This aint street drugs you can test, and once its in you theres no removing it without a full blood transfusion or super complicated filtration process to replace your serum albumin.
To each his own. Im looking to become more percent lead, mercury, and asbestos so for me its perfect.

This should be taken with a grain of salt. Pat Gelsinger himself was in the CSuite position when they legendary fired 1000 managers in 2006. He has very good knowledge of internal processes and how fast Intel can get bloated, its not the first time in this companys history. The bigger problem was once Pat came into play he was not focused on efficiency but solving the current issues with brute force. Meaning throwing as much money and people at it as possible. The issue that came into play that he slightly miscalculated how far Intel was actually behind. His famous philosophy back then was that by each generational cycle the competition came out Intel already offers 2. We can really see this in the current roadmap were Intel comes out with new products in way under 12 months in each space. When AMD and TSMC doesnt get their act together Intel will leapfrog them in 2025. This isnt the first time Intel has done this in its history. The issue now is that Intel is a long term play and in a currently not favorable position. Wall Street does not like that. They want fast money, fast quarterly results and dont care about anything else really. Now with the recent news about activist investors iam quite sure this news is fabricated by activist investors who manipulate the media in the background to gain shareholders favor. Dont fall for it. Intel wants to protect themselves from activist investors because they would try to split the company apart for the short term gain. If they would enter Intel is done. I really hope Pat will live long enough to see how what incredible work he has done. In 2025 we will see a very competitive Intel and in 2026 current Wallstreet critics will be very very silent. Just remember the fights Jensen had with Wallstreet back then. Now they love him.

So Im going to take this a slightly different direction. Real Mistakes Intel has made 1. Looking into Holographic DUV rather than going all in on EUV. This is what caused them to lose their market position. This was the result of bean counters hoping the cheaper process would be good enough, but while it worked the yield rates were too low causing it to become uneconomically viable and forcing intel to not shrink their chips for multiple generations to maintain economic viability. 2. Some bugoversight causing 13th 14th gen chips to damage themselves slowly with overvoltage issues. They say they have it under control now with the new microcode update. Only time will tell if that is true. Mistakes INVESTORS are worried about that we dont know the outcome of yet 1. Massive investments into new fabs without a clear roadmap, clientele, etc who will use their contracting services. This makes their balance sheet look like shit and if they dont get some big clients this will be a gigantic waste of money. 2. Their mistakes and anticonsumer approaches are degrading a core customer base in the server sector. AMD is also going after the server market more aggressively. This puts their long term market position in jeopardy. 3. They are making a lot of long term bets on things like GPUs that are hemmoraging money. While I believe this is probably best for them in the long term investors want their money this quarter and these types of plays are just not what they want to see. Reasons to be optimistic 1. Their current chips have honestly caught up to AMD. The 14th gen that arent killing themselves match or exceed the top AMD chips in a wide variety of tasks. 7800X3D is overall best gaming GPU but after that there is a long list of great performance cpus from intel. 2. The 9000 series from AMD is overall a bit of a dud. VERY little benefit over the 7000 series which a large part of the 14th gen already was beating. The 7800X3D still best for consumers and while most of the benefits for the 9000 series is for servers and heavey multithreaded workloads the jump isnt particularly impressive and well below what we normally expect for a generational leap. If 15th generation even an average boost compared to 14th gen its VERY likely intel takes a clear lead in the market. My take. Intel is making multiple long term plays and people are getting super ancy because they have had 2 major mistakes in the last decade. These are really risky gambles with hundreds of billions of dollars and if even 1 of these turns out to be a complete failure it will be a huge issue for the company. By end of 2025 first service fabs will be online, battlemage gpus will be out, and we will know if 15th gen is better than 9000 series or if they also stumble like AMD on this generational update. Given the massive hits in their recent stock, there likely is a lot of upside potential IF they pull it off. The idea they are risk adverse to me doesnt really track with their current heavy investment strategy. The culture might be risk adverse but they are playing with fire here. Messing up and having another microcode issue is something they CANT afford. AMDs messups are giving them an opportunity to regain their footing and we wont know how this plays out until probably end of next year. I expect the stock to go down or stay put until we see how these bets pay off and any investment in INTEL is just betting on this stuff working out. Only project that has me super worried for them is the contract fabs. Its REALLY not clear who they would be getting contract work from. Unless they get an Nvidia, Qualcomm, etc style client I honestly DONT know how they can justify the cost and I just dont see any of those companies leaving TSMC in a serious capacity. There just arent many customers in the world that can even use this service and stealing them from TSMC wont be easy.
I feel like Microsoft made a comeback after a similar rut. Perhaps Intel can too. Ive got 3 shares though, so Im probably thinking wishfully.

replies.text: One IMPORTANT item to consider. Yes, you can hold master limited partnerships MLPs EPD ET are MLPs in a traditional or Roth IRA. However, MLP income over 1,000 annually is taxable, which can create tax liabilities for the account. This is because the IRA becomes a limited partner in the MLP, and the tax code treats the partners as if they are directly earning the MLPs income. Look up unrelated business taxable income UBTI.

replies.text: The yields are high but look at the real returns after you factor in the NAV erosion.

they take a pile of cash, they divide this pile of cash into two stacks. one stack they use to buy government bonds. this does two things. one, it preserves the capital used to buy bonds. two, the interest from the bonds can be used to provide part of the monthly dividend. second stack is used to buy and sell options. cony deals with coin options. tsly deals with tsla options, aply deals with aapl options.

Theyre giving you back your own money after charging a 0.99 fee I mean, almost. They have huge distributions while the NAV declines substantially. Ask theyre giving you back your own money as a dividend

replies.text: Reminder you make money in the market when you buy low and sell high. Selling because the market is down is assbackwards but everyone loves to do it.
What here proves it is impossible to time the market?

Timing the market in this way is more or less impossible. For the basic reason that the future is unknown and unknowable. But, buying more when the market is down DOES work. So if you have cash lying around that you dont need in the next couple years, you should be buying today.

what about missing the 10 worst days ? These stats are misleading, because if you miss the best days you also will miss the worst days by chance
I was panic selling puts when VIX was at 50..the only thing I regret now is not selling more!
If you miss out on the markets worst days, you probably be much richer too. I just felt peoples argument is weird.
The folks panic selling this morning are already missing out on gains.

There was a study done on the Norwegian market, on real trades from 1997 2020. It turns out we not only can, but retail investors do know how and when to go in and out of the market. Retail investors have beaten the market in the time period. Source for those interested, it is free
I sold a very large position in SPY last month at 545 and bought back in this morning at 520. Its not impossible by any stretch of the imagination.
Timing the market perfectly is impossible

Timing the market ahead of time is impossible. Timing the market after the fact is not. When the market tanks, take out of cash and buy more. replies.text: If its just a one time huge gain event, then you may not have to worry about paying estimated taxes. There are two ways to not be penalized by the IRS when you have underpaid throughout the year Your filed tax return shows you owe less than 1,000 or You paid at least 90 of the tax shown on the return for the taxable year or 100 of the tax shown on the return for the prior year, whichever amount is less. If your adjusted gross income AGI for 2023 was more than 150,000 75,000 if your filing status for 2024 is married filing separately, substitute 110 for 100. The 2nd bullet point is most important, you need to make sure you pay enough taxes this year to match what your total taxes was last year. Look at Line 24 on your 1040. If you got a refund last year and also got a raise from your employer, then probably in the clear. Adjust your witholding otherwise.

You estimate how much taxes you would pay in order to not get penalized for not paying the estimated taxes. The responsibility is on you to do that calculation. If you dont want to figure it out yourself, consult a tax professional, and they will advise you about the rules around estimated taxes and will help you figure out how much and when to pay, if at all.
You can pay online, you identify it as 1040 Est for 2024. You dont need to pay quarterly. You might want to pay due to a windfall that has no withholding from it, or other unexpected taxable event.
Thank you all for the advice. Appreciate it.

replies.text: There are some fine nuances between an individual retirement account ira and a 401k which is a company sponsored retirement plan as you say, the 401k has a much higher savings limit, money is held in trust, and can be saved pre tax. IRA is individual, so lower limit and your contributions may or may not be deductible to your taxes. 401ks alow loans and usually a slew of hardship distributions. Iras you have control and can withdraw the money no loans and pay penalties. 401k usually has a menu of funds to choose among. Ira has pretty much all funds, stocks and bonds, at a broker or bank account.

The two main tradeoffs are Contribution limits 401k has 3x the limit of IRA. How much do you want to save for retirement? Hint You dont have to pick one OR the other you can do BOTH! Investment options Your employer will almost always have a limited number of investment options available which is not, in itself, a bad thing theyll have one of each of the major fund classes, probably. ALSO, you get the tax saving in each paycheck dont have to wait for the end of the year to deduct your contrib. Your individual account will have a considerably broader spectrum of mutual and exchangetraded funds to choose from. This may or may not be a big deal. The next biggest diff is some details pertaining to withdrawals, which presumably you wont have to worry about for a while yet. IF the 401k has a decent selection of funds, you should start there if at all possible, just for its higher limit alone. After all, when was the last time you heard someone say, Geez, I think I saved too much for retirement, eh?

Just a dude so please confirm 401k legal protection is federal but ira protection from legal action differs per state. 401k includes the rule of 55. The lists above are importantly too but thought I would add these.

401k contributions are pretaxed which will lower your annual income, so you will pay less tax. if possible, contribute the max. allowable annual limit roth ira contributions are posttax. it is better to take money currently in your saving to open a roth account bc you have already paid tax on it. 2 biggest advantages with the roth ira are a you can withdraw your contribution any time taxfree and penaltyfree b after 5 yrs, you can also withdraw the gains or interest earned taxfree and penaltyfree. first time home buyer can withdraw the earning with limit before the 5 yrs taxfree penalty free as well. withdrawal must be used for home purchase! good luck.

A 401k is a retirement account usually through a persons job that has a contribution limit 23,000 for 2024 older individuals have higher limit where contributions are income deductible. An IRA is also a retirement account where you have to open yourself with a contribution limit of 7,000 for 2024 older individuals also have higher limits. 401ks have limited products youre able to invest in based on the administrator. IRAs have near unlimited options of what you can regularly buy in any other brokerage account. There are other tax nuances and income limits with an IRA Roth vs Traditional but thats the quick intro to both accounts.

The contribution limit is obviously a big difference. 401ks are set up through your employer and generally have more rules and limitations than an IRA. Depending on your income you may not be able to deduct your Traditional IRA contribution in which case you should contribute to a Roth IRA or do Backdoor Roth if your income is too high to contribute to a Roth IRA
Get the full match from your employer, itsfree money. If they have matching Then overflow goes to an IRA until that is maxed out. Then max out your 401k after that.

replies.text: Weak form is true in most markets where you have access to historical data. Semi strong form is likely true in a lot of highly covered markets such as the US large cap space. Strong form certainly isnt true. US large cap is probably the most efficient market and hardest to beat. Fixed income as a whole is quite inefficient and is easier to beat.
Strong emh has been disproven. Weak emh somewhat stands

Hockey is not a market. EMH is like betting on hockey. If one team is stronger than another, you will be offered worse odds, such that the EV is equal to betting on the weaker team. Same with stocks. If one company makes more money than another, it will be priced higher such that the expected return is the same as the other. The market aggregates the weighted information from many participants and should be more accurate than even a wellinformed person. 1. EMH is a model. All models are wrong yet some are useful in some contexts. 2. EMH is a good starting point and you should justify any deviation from EMH, not the other way around. 2. Corollary you should not ignore anything just because it mentions EMH 3. Caveat you also should not ignore any purported deviation from EMH 2. Prices can only be efficient if people are doing the research and trading to make them that way. So markets can never be totally efficient. There is always some ephemeral edge and make money from it. 3. But you probably arent among them generalized you. Certainly the average investor cannot be. Expertise, resources, networks. 4. Fees. Whatever alpha someone might have, they will try to extract roughly all of it from their investors in fees. And on average managers cant have alpha since they compete against each other, but they can charge plenty of fees.

Also I dont believe price are ever right tbh. Forecasting the future is hard. I like to say that the market is statistically efficient in that prices arent necessarily reflecting the future but no one really has an edge based on the current information we have. uswole_bodry I think he put it very accurately here. Prices are as accurate at any given moment as what people are willing to trade them at. On every side of a trade there is a buyer and a seller with different motives. One may be in retirement and wants to buy a vacation. One may be an index fund buyer blindly chocking away a paycheck. Many are people buying who think the sellers are stupid and many are sellers thinking the buyers are stupid. Some just lost their job and need to derisk. Some just watched a tiktok who told them to buy. We are selling to willing buyers at the fair market price.

I dont get the hockey analogy. Even if most market participants arent pros, EMH is about the pros rapidly incorporating all available info into prices. Theres endless data to show its very hard to beat the market consistently and without excess risk. That said, anyone who spent 5 minutes outside a classroom and on the street knows true strong form EMH is not true. Think of it more like a base case assumption the deviations are interesting, often profitable, but often ephemeral. This article has a few examples. Theres plenty of times an unrelated stock with a similar ticker rallies on a merger announcement. That alone invalidates strong EMH. Market manipulation like pump and dumps wouldnt even exist if strong EMH were true.

I dont really love hockey. So its hard for me to appreciate your analogy. But regarding stock picking about 95 of the population is not smart enough or have enough time to consistently outperform the sp500 or VTI total market index 95 of people should stick to index funds and realize the market is smarter than they are. If you somehow think you are in the 5 who could out perform the market give it a shot. I hope the excessive hours of stress and research are worth the tiny bit of alpha you can achieve. Year after year.

The fact that there is a profitable incentive to being information to market is exactly why it is efficient. There is extraordinary competition to being information to market. Its not PERFECTLY efficient, that is an impossibility, but its extremely efficient to the point where most active managers fail to outperform their benchmark net of costs.
Survivorship bias
Markets arent perfectly efficient but they are efficient enough that for most people, acting like it is efficient yields the best results.

idk emh, but the premise of 100 efficiency in a dynamic market of opposing forces isnt very smart. if that was accurate, such an efficiency model would have been replicated to solve others world problems

Anyone who believes in EMH has no real experience trading the market. Look at the smart money in 2022 or practically any time, with bonds constantly pricing no more hikes even as Powell continued to say that they were not done hiking. Equities are even dumber, as anyone over at WSB can tell you. Are there explanations flows, greeks, politics for obvious and massive idiocy in the market? Sure, but damn is it inefficient.

Is this built on the BS that people are rational actors? We know thats not true. And there were studies I think in the 60s that showed this, economics people were blown away and had never thought that people could act irrationally.

The arms race amongst those extracting fractions of a penny is truly colossal. Regular investors no matter how smart and dedicated, dont have the same tools, access, and money. You can buy nanosecond latency to the market. Whereas most ppl have many milliseconds at best. Does it matter? Yes. Cuz they found ways for it to matter. If you find a way to extract a penny a trade, that will easily get swallowed by brokers fees. So they have different pay structures. This is the day trading and algorithm trading from a laypersons view. Can you do it? Sure. Will you make money? Theres something like a 90 chance no. And if you do, it will be insignificant compared to just buy and hold. So your analogy is like having NHL guys on the ice and then sending a really dedicated fan out there. In his tennis shoes and shorts with a broom as a stick. He might score. Totally possible.
I dont know how anyone can claim any markets are anywhere near efficient with a straight face when META went from 90 to 600 in 2 years.

This is EXACTLY how I feel, thanks so much for your comment. Its just challenging to maintain all facts at once, especially when the professor is literally a famous economist. Really appreciate your post.
Way less than 5, even the top investment advisors rarely beat the SP500 funds.

Hi, thanks for your response. The issue with your perspective is that I cite consistent outperformance, or alpha. Youre referring to random outperformance. If we took a thousand adults and put them against mcdavid in an NHL game, its highly likely that a few of those adults will outperform McDavid in one or two games over the course of their sample. Imagine I manage to outscore mcdavid in an NHL game, that he broke his leg in, clearly I got lucky. In the same way a gold fish would be lucky to beat warren buffet. Let 1000 gold fish pick 1,000 random stocks. Many of them will outperform buffets picks. That doesnt mean you should trust your leading gold fish over brk.b. On the other hand it would make sense to continue to expect mcdavid or whatever to continue to outperform.
Repeating my other comment I dont know how anyone can claim any markets are anywhere near efficient with a straight face when META went from 90 to 600 in 2 years.

EMH isnt a religion or a selfimprovement philosophy, so it isnt a matter of whether one believes in it or not. Its a testable hypothesis about financial markets that says market prices fully incorporate the available information. It doesnt say that market prices are always right, just that market prices dont systematically leave free money on the table. My limited familiarity with the empirical literature is very dated, but if I wanted to challenge literally a famous economist about it Id ask him which published studies to read in order to argue the issue professionally, rather than make awkward sports analogies.

Economists know it isnt true, but we use this concept to simplify our expectations about individuals. Economists account for this by explaining certain biases of ours to be our tendency towards risk aversion or time preference. It is completely illogical to purchase home insurance if youre trying to maximize your weatlh, because the costs of insurance dont just cover the risk of your house burning down, but they also cover the operating costs of the insurance company. Yet an individual who under no circumstances is willing to risk losing their home, will maximize their overall happiness by covering these costs and purchasing home insurance because they will feel significantly safer and have a more stable life on average.

I think your knowledge of economics is maybe not quite as robust as you think. Herbert Simon introduced the notion of satisficing a deviation from the more common assumption of rational optimization as early as 1947. More recently, Daniel Kahneman and Vernon Smith won a Nobel Memorial prize for their work in behavioural economics in 2002, as did Richard Thaler in 2017.
Dude, you have no idea what youre talking about. Providing liquidity has very little to do with incorporating information about a business into the stock.

I think an efficient market is different from a rational market. In my mind, efficiency just refers to how quickly new info is priced in, but has no influence on reaction size from this news or bullishness in general.

I think youre not defining efficient markets correctly. An efficient market is defined as a market that is pricing in all relevant information. Efficient markets makes no claim on the quality of that information, or for unknown variables, merely that all known information is already reflected in the market price. This is important because if you invest in the company on the basis of it being innovative or strong, this may be insufficient to justify a long position in the company, because the market has already priced it in.
And strong EMH is empirically incorrect. If you persist in believing it it, then clearly it is a religion to you.
Its not a testable hypothesis lmao. How can it possibly be unless you have all available information?
Are you operating under the delusion that this is a question about economics? It is a question about reality.

Thats a made up definition of EMH. Spend some time googling before saying these things your headcanon doesnt match the assumptions behind EMH, which relies on the existence of a perfect market with rational investors.
bruh this is a discussion, no one is trying to beat anyone the goal is for every party involved to come out of the discussion with a more nuanced understanding of the world

I think youre not understanding the point Im making. It should be impossible to generate almost 600 returns from one of the largest, most liquid, most covered stocks in the world. Strong EMH holds that its impossible to make excess returns for any level of risk. 600 returns is almost BK shitco territory. Even if you thought META was a melting ice cube, you dont get compensated that much for holding those lmao look at stocks like mall REITs, cigarettes, print newspaper stocks, etc.

As I said, I dont think belief is the right way to frame the issue. IIRC, I also said my knowledge about the empirical evidence is dated, so you may well be right. Or not I honestly dont know. But if someone wants to argue with an academic who presumably does know the subject, it would make sense to me to read at least some of the literature.

Youre the smartest in the room arent you? Most of the EMH assumptions do not perfectly hold and for that reason I dont believe in perfect efficiency. Regarding rational investors investing based on all available information, they can absolutely cause a market rally. That doesnt make the market irrational.

Youre missing the part that asset prices reflect all KNOWN information or that information is poor quality. Unknown information is not reflected on the market price. If a company like Meta performs in a manner that is unexpected, then the market will adjust their expectations accordingly. Regardless, over 15 year time horizons, only around 12 of actively managed funds were able to outperform their benchmark after fees in the US and similar internationally. This is what we would expect, assuming that nobody had any known information that hadnt already been priced in. Its good evidence that outperformance of active managers during short term time frames are likely due to luck. Another study looked at the performance of actively managed funds and found that 17 of the top quartile funds remained top quartile over a 5 year period. Again, what we would expect in an efficient market. Im also not trying to say that markets are perfectly efficient. Its just a model, and not a perfect reflection of real markets, exceptions do exist, but those exceptions dont detract from the main point. Even if you dont agree that markets are efficient, its undeniable that an efficient markets framework helps passive and active investors alike. All too often I see investors on reddit look at raw company performance, but they never consider the markets expectations. In order to profit actively trading, you need to assess how the market is wrong and have really good proof that youre right, but good luck. When we say markets are efficient, we are saying that there is a really competitive market to process information. High frequency traders invest billions of dollars in slightly faster cables just to have lower latency than their competitors. This is who youre competing against. You can see markets react real time whenever Jerome Powell speaks. This is a sign that new information adjusts real time. I like to say that markets are statistically efficient, but not fundamentally efficient as all pricing is based on estimates of fundamental outcomes that are unknown. Its nearly impossible for market participants to gain an edge of taking advantage of fundamental inefficiencies because the market has provided a profitable incentive for market makers, information traders and liquidity providers to make the market statistically efficient.

Im pretty intelligent, yes, but intelligence is table stakes to invest. More importantly I try my best to not spout bullshit especially if its an area I dont specialize in. You can refer to another comment of mine in here unless you felt like META was going bankrupt, 600 returns should not be in a reasonable distribution of outcomes. So no not rational. No serious people thought META was going to zero in the next 5 years.

A Some people on here will be professors, and able to improve or criticise my perspective. As I asked for in the OP Advice You should be seeking this discussion with people who are highly educated in finance, not random redditors. The rate of Econ Masters degree in my country suggests that a few of the 3k people whove read this post are educated enough to respond. If the post wasnt intended for you, or you dont feel like responding, its perfectly fine to move on. Your comments have been pretty toxic tbth, its perfectly fine to say nothing if you have nothing to add.

Youre missing the part that asset prices reflect all KNOWN information or that information is poor quality. Unknown information is not reflected on the market price. If a company like Meta performs in a manner that is unexpected, then the market will adjust their expectations accordingly. This should be impossible according to the strong form of EMH, ALL available information is incorporated, both public and private. So no not missing anything. EMH suggests that everything Zuckerberg knows would be built into the market, which is clearly wrong. Also, even if you assume a weaker version of EMH take a look at how EPS estimates changed for META. Did they go up 600 for 2025E? No. Regardless, over 15 year time horizons, only around 12 of actively managed funds were able to outperform their benchmark after fees in the US and similar internationally. This is what we would expect, assuming that nobody had any known information that hadnt already been priced in. Its good evidence that outperformance of active managers during short term time frames are likely due to luck. That most active managers underperform is not evidence of EMH. Alpha is inherently zero sum, and if you are able to generate alpha, you will attract the majority of assets. This is what we have seen with multimanagers who have vastly more resources than single man shops. So you should expect excess returns to be concentrated in 50 of assets after transaction costs, the majority of which will be earned by a limited few participants. Im also not trying to say that markets are perfectly efficient. Its just a model, and not a perfect reflection of real markets, exceptions do exist, but those exceptions dont detract from the main point. Even if you dont agree that markets are efficient, its undeniable that an efficient markets framework helps passive and active investors alike. All too often I see investors on reddit look at raw company performance, but they never consider the markets expectations. In order to profit actively trading, you need to assess how the market is wrong and have really good proof that youre right, but good luck. I dont disagree with this. The market is a tough game. Anybody who thinks this is easy is an idiot. But I dont think you can take away anything from EMH except that trying to generate alpha is extremely difficult to the point where unless youre in the 95th percentile, its probably not worth being more than a hobby for your average investor, and that you have to think about what other market participants are thinking and doing. However, inefficiencies exist all the time, which EMH postulates should never happen. Its inherently defeatist which I very much disagree with. It is very possible to find oneoff efficiencies and profit off them, and you should certainly try to capitalize on those when they come up this stance is one where most of this subreddit would blindly disagree with me on. Doing it day in, day out is a different matter. I used to be a professional investor and was a consistent alpha generator for my fund, but it took a lot of resources probably spent over 200K a year on research. Now as a retired individual investor, I still outperform with my long picks, but those opportunities only become apparent to me maybe two or three times a year and usually among broader market selloffs for example, the last longs I bought were back in Oct 2023 LIN, ASML, TRU, MLM, SE and August this year LULU, UNH, SHW, BROS note I dont necessarily hold all these still for anybody who reads this and wants to bandwagon, dont take this as an indicator I still own these businesses or advice.

Lmao you clearly dont specialize in this. Your other comments are arguing that EMH doesnt hold because Meta went from 90 to 600 which has absolutely nothing to do with EMH. Why would EMH prevent this? EMH does not preclude individual stocks from outperforming the market. EMH deals with how quickly new information is absorbed by the market and the idea that if the market is efficient, it is extremely difficult to beat the market.

This should be impossible according to the strong form of EMH, ALL available information is incorporated, both public and private. So no not missing anything. EMH suggests that everything Zuckerberg knows would be built into the market, which is clearly wrong. Respectfully I think youre arguing a straw man. I have not met any prominent EMH believer who makes the claim that markets are strong form efficient. Not even Eugene Fama himself believes this. In fact, strong form efficiency is an impossibility, It creates a paradox referred to as the GrossmanStiglitz paradox. If markets were perfectly efficient, active managers wouldnt waste their resources bringing information to market, and if active managers no longer bring information to market, than markets are no longer efficient. Also, even if you assume a weaker version of EMH take a look at how EPS estimates changed for META. Did they go up 600 for 2025E? No. I havent looked at the data myself, but Ill give you the benefit of the doubt and assume this is market inefficiency. Even so, cherry picking one or a couple of instances of a market inefficiency does not justify throwing out the model. In fact, I think it is a model that is super important for active managers to incorporate into their own stock picks. To go further than that, I think the Adaptive Markets Hypothesis expands on EMH and allows active managers to determine the extent markets are efficient and how much alpha is available to them. That most active managers underperform is not evidence of EMH. Alpha is inherently zero sum, and if you are able to generate alpha, you will attract the majority of assets... I disagree. This supports the idea that markets become more efficient with time. If bad managers die out, what is left are the good managers which you mention have most of the assets. These good managers survive presumably because they are actually good managers and have good information, whereas the bad managers might survive for a short time due to luck but eventually die out. To further hammer this point home, some really successful active managers need to cap their funds, because their strategies cannot scale. Renaissance technology is a great example of this. The fact that their strategy can no longer accommodate additional capital should support the market efficiency idea. I dont disagree with this. The market is a tough game. Anybody who thinks this is easy is an idiot. But I dont think you can take away anything from EMH except that trying to generate alpha is extremely difficult to the point where unless youre in the 95th percentile, its probably not worth being more than a hobby for your average investor, and that you have to think about what other market participants are thinking and doing. I agree with everything you said here. However, inefficiencies exist all the time, which EMH postulates should never happen. This is why I think we disagree. This is a strawman youre arguing against. Plain and simple. Even the strongest EMH proponents do not believe this is true, it would be paradoxical to think otherwise, and like I mentioned, Eugene Fama himself does not believe this to be true. Its inherently defeatist which I very much disagree with. It is very possible to find oneoff efficiencies and profit off them, and you should certainly try to capitalize on those when they come up this stance is one where most of this subreddit would blindly disagree with me on. Doing it day in, day out is a different matter. I used to be a professional investor and was a consistent alpha generator for my fund, but it took a lot of resources probably spent over 200K a year on research. Respectfully, I am skeptical of claims random Redditors make lol. Out of curiosity, how did you justify those long positions? I genuinely think that the efficient markets framework is an integral component of successful stock selection, and even more so with an adaptive markets framework. I hope you were successful though, and I hope you remain an active manager. Your commitment to bring information to market is exactly why passive investing strategies work for a couple of basis points a year .

EMH precludes you from earning excess returns at a given level of risk. I am telling you that 600 unlevered returns over 2 years are comfortably beyond the expected returns for a large cap US stock. It is beyond the expected returns for any stock unless its a very low probability outcome I mostly only saw this for extremely bizarre circumstances i.e., a company about to go BK getting their debt forgiven, a shitco microcap putting out a pump and dump release saying theyre in acquisition talks with a reputable co, etc.. This didnt happen with META. The bear case was pretty known then TikTok and macro concerns. NA users went negative in Feb 2022. But if zero wasnt on the table in the next 5 years for META, then you earned returns well over what you should get on a comfortably solvent business. So theres at least one exception to EMH. If you start making up different variants of EMH and start saying oh yeah exceptions exist, this devolves into the market is tough, which I do agree with, but is a pointless discussion. Some information is incorporated into the market. It is impossible to tell to what extent, but its nowhere near all available information. It is possible to earn excess riskadjusted returns. Does this help you understand the relationship between META and EMH now?
