Keep it up if youd like though, its amusing and shows insecurity.
Hey sorry, I just saw this Ill respond in the morning.

Ill try and address all your points, but I dont actually think youre disagreeing with me on anything and were just talking past each other. I had to split this into two parts given length. From what I can tell, you are arguing the spirit of EMH is that markets are competitive. My stance is 1. The market is not anywhere close to perfectly efficient. It does not incorporate all public information, all private information, nor even necessarily historical price action. This is in direct contradiction to the textbook definition of all three forms of EMH. I am not disputing other theories that Im not versed on such as adaptive market hypothesis, nor am I disputing that markets get more competitive over time. 2. As a consequence of the market not being perfectly efficient, there are opportunities for a fundamental investor. I think people use the EMH as an excuse to shit on active managers, and in this subreddit in particular, also as an excuse to shut down aspiring analysts and most discussion of individual securities on here using the its priced in!!! meme. 3. As I said before, this doesnt mean its easy though. Im not going to belabor this point further as I believe we both understand. Going back to your very first comment The fact that there is a profitable incentive to being information to market is exactly why it is efficient. There is extraordinary competition to being information to market. I disagree with the bolded part. Its not efficient. It becomes more efficient by the day, but it is not efficient. Its not PERFECTLY efficient, that is an impossibility, but its extremely efficient to the point where most active managers fail to outperform their benchmark net of costs. I think you and I disagree on the extent of efficiency, but hard to tell given you never explicitly quantify this. However, theres definitively no linkage here between the first part of the sentence and the second, which I address later in this comment. Now directly addressing your most recent comment Respectfully I think youre arguing a straw man. I have not met any prominent EMH believer who makes the claim that markets are strong form efficient. I disagree. This supports the idea that markets become more efficient with time. If bad managers die out, what is left are the good managers which you mention have most of the assets. These good managers survive presumably because they are actually good managers and have good information, whereas the bad managers might survive for a short time due to luck but eventually die out. Markets do become more efficient over time. I never disagreed with this. But half, or even most of the active managers underperforming means nothing with regards to how efficient the market is. Alpha is zero sum. This is the definition of alpha as the residual of the regression of stock market prices against a given factor, it is not up for debate that the residuals have to add up to zero. As a consequence, there is no linkage between most active managers underperforming and the market being efficient. At either extreme of market being entirely efficient and not efficient at all, each dollar of positive alpha has to be offset by a dollar of negative alpha. If you are stating here that the market gets more competitive as assets aggregate to managers that consistently generate alpha, I am not arguing against this at all as a former practitioner, this was never in contention and I like to think that the job was tough and I competed hard for my paychecks against the platforms. But this doesnt serve as any indication as to how effectively information is priced in. This is why I think we disagree. This is a strawman youre arguing against. Plain and simple. Even the strongest EMH proponents do not believe this is true, it would be paradoxical to think otherwise, and like I mentioned, Eugene Fama himself does not believe this to be true. I spoke incorrectly. I should not have said never. However, EMH does hold that inefficiencies should not be repeatedly exploitable. If you believe that there are managers who consistently generate alpha, which I believe you do given you mentioned RenTech, then for them to generate that consistent alpha, there has to be consistent inefficiencies, which is what Im arguing for. Btw, youre a bit liberal with the term strawman. My original comment was just flat out wrong, but not every incorrect statement is a strawman. If by efficient markets framework you just mean understand that the market is competitive, and chances are that the WSJ headline youre excited about was probably priced in 6 months ago, then yeah. Regarding justifying positions its understanding how the market thinks about a business, and if theres something thats either underappreciated or unappreciated, its diligencing that aspect, quantifying it in your model with EVIDENCE, which most people dont have the rigor to do, and if theres material difference in the KPIs the market is looking at, then you either go long or short. For example, take WOLF they manufacture silicon carbide wafers and they were a monopoly circa 20182019. I was able to prove that there was price compression and competition on the way. It was trading at like infinity times revenue, and sellside was falling over themselves upgrading the stock. Getting quotes from Crees salespeople, there was about 10 compression in ASPs each year. So I plug this into my model, see how this compares vs. how most people are thinking about the business and what it would look like 3 years out, and if there was a favorable riskreward skew, Id short it. I think I was below consensus by like 20 percentage points on gm, which is enormous. I hope you were successful though, and I hope you remain an active manager. They are shooting themselves in the foot because active management is precisely why markets became efficient and why their strategy works to begin with. For what its worth, I would not consider my self completely under the passive umbrella. I too employ a semiactive strategy, overweighting certain stocks on partly on the basis that there are prevailing behavioral inefficiencies driving differences in returns momentum, value, etc. Regarding the Bessembinder paper, if you consider the extreme volatility of individual stocks, its no wonder that many go to zero and most of them underperform treasury bills, thats just basic statistics. But most of that volatility can just be diversified away. I dont exactly see why this contradicts EMH. I believe I mentioned before viewing markets as statistically efficient not fundamentally efficient. All prices are based on fundamental outcomes that are unknown. EMH doesnt make the claim that prices are right, merely that all known information is incorporated into the market price. half of or even most active managers underperforming is not evidence for EMH. I disagree here. The key here is persistence. Its not just that they underperform, but that those that are top quartile at one point in time seldom remain top quartile. This means that either that they were lucky, or their strategy no longer became profitable because any market inefficiency already got arbitraged away. Again why the best active managers will refuse to take your money. a bit liberal with the word strawman. Sorry, it wasnt my intention to accuse you of intentionally straw manning or arguing in bad faith. Im just trying to say, I dont know of any academic who argues for strong form efficiency, hence youre arguing against a position that no one that I know of really has.

Right back at you. I never defined EMH the way you quoted it. I also acknowledged the rationality of market participants, however Im saying that strong or weak performance doesnt imply irrationality. Ive already said I dont believe the EMH is true, but strong returns from one stock in no way disproves it on its own. I mean look at NVDA, you can argue that EMH is wrong because of its returns but those returns are backed by new info being absorbed by the market increased chip demand, increased progress on next gen chips, profitability, future outlook of Huang, etc.. NVDA and META are not risky businesses in the sense that everybody knows theyre not going to fail anytime soon, however, they are risky stocks from a volatility perspective. Is that due to behavioral biases of investors and does that make them irrational? Or is it due to those being highly watched stocks where the info is absorbed so quickly by so many people the moves are hard and fast? Could be either. One of those explanations would disprove an assumption of EMH and the other is in favour of EMH. My only disagreement is that EMH does not preclude stocks from outperforming the market. If EMH were true, it would prevent investors from consistently outperforming on a risk adjusted basis which includes business risk, industry risk, stock volatility, as well as total portfolio risk and volatility holding 100 META is absolutely riskier than holding 100 SPY so should earn higher returns.

Warning, essay ahead haha. Drank some coffee a bit too late this evening. Your original comment Weak form is true in most markets where you have access to historical data. Semi strong form is likely true in a lot of highly covered markets such as the US large cap space. Strong form certainly isnt true. US large cap is probably the most efficient market and hardest to beat. Fixed income as a whole is quite inefficient and is easier to beat. The EMH specifically states that share prices reflect all available information from a given set of information and then the different forms of EMH split this down into the universes of information public and private strong, public only semistrong and then whatever is visible from price action weak. All the forms of EMH state that ALL available information from a certain universe of info is incorporated, and I disagree 100 with at least 2 of the three not being a trader, I have minimal expertise to be able to opine on the possibility of generating alpha from prior price action, although I do believe the persistent outperformance of momentum as a factor to be a ding against this as well. For clarification, weak form holds that investing off price action doesnt work, semi holds that all public information is incorporated, and strong holds that all information is totally incorporated is the generally accepted definition paraphrased. This was a quote of myself. You never actually define the EMH. My original comment was meant to indicate complete disagreement with 2, potentially 3 of the iterations of EMH, and therefore disagreement with your comment that semi strong form is likely true. You then go on to say I think an efficient market is different from a rational market. In my mind, efficiency just refers to how quickly new info is priced in, but has no influence on reaction size from this news or bullishness in general. Efficient markets are rational. You define efficient market differently from how the EMH defines it. Efficient markets have to be rational but rational markets dont have to be efficient, true, but I dont believe thats what you were saying here. You then go on to claim that efficiency is not linked to magnitude of moves. New info does have influence on reaction size. There have definitely been earnings where the company has reported, stock is up 8 but my EPS estimates go up 15 so I am a buyer of the stock. This is an efficient process I am incorporating my views into the stock price. So how do I interpret your claim that efficiency is not related to magnitude of reactionary moves? People will get things wrong, but people will try to quantify and price new information, which leads to buying and selling and is a process that improves pricing of securities. This is not a correct claim, and this is when I tell you that you need to Google things or know what youre talking about. I also acknowledged the rationality of market participants Market participants try to be rational, but I think there are many many times where they arent. I dont think we have material disagreements here though.

Im saying that strong or weak performance doesnt imply irrationality. Strong returns from one stock where the price implied an unrealistic range of outcomes DOES imply irrationality exists. I was being flippant in my very first comment to you, but hopefully my 3rd and latter comments made it clear that I am not saying hey one stock did well, so therefore EMH cant hold. Returns alone dont prove that, but I am providing context supporting my belief that theres no way META pricing was reflecting all available information from any universe of possible information. I am saying that one stock was priced as if it was going out of business when it was highly profitable, had room to take expense out of the opex line, and even if you baked in secular decline which I was a believer in at the time, price still didnt make sense. Even the most bearish of my peers didnt understand the price action TMT analysts at MLP, p72, etc., so there wasnt any widespread fundamental narrative there was no new fundamental information being incorporated. This is a large cap stock, where sure, you take on idiosyncratic risk, but realistically most people dont expect these to outperform SPX by more than 500 bps, certainly dont expect them to post 300 returns over any 12 month time frame. I will tell you that nobody expects to earn 500 of outperformance owning a megacap tech stock over a 2 year span, which is what META did from Nov 4, 2022 to now. Ive already said I dont believe the EMH is true, but strong returns from one stock in no way disproves it on its own. You earlier said you believe the semistrong form to hold true. As mentioned above, my comments to other users in this thread before we even started discussing my later comments to you should have made it abundantly clear that its not just me saying a stock outperformed so EMH doesnt hold. In my other comments to users, I said that these returns are commensurate with what you would hope to get holding absolute garbage and junk with GME, Chinese ADR frauds, that type of thing in mind. Not what youd expect to earn holding a mix of quality, size, and internet exposure, and idiosyncratic business risk informed by my experience as a hopefully knowledgeable fundamental analyst didnt explain what was incorporated into price either. You only need one exception to disprove a hypothesis. I also dont see the linkage between small sample size and me having a misunderstanding of EMH. To that end, if youd said that sample size were the qualm for you, I wouldve pointed you to Bessembinders study showing that 57 of stocks failed to outperform TREASURIES over the past 100 years. How can that be remotely close to efficient when you are supposed to be compensated for bearing idiosyncratic risk? But thats not what you asked for. You just said that I dont understand what Im talking about. NVDA and META are not risky businesses in the sense that everybody knows theyre not going to fail anytime soon, however, they are risky stocks from a volatility perspective. Is that due to behavioral biases of investors and does that make them irrational? Or is it due to those being highly watched stocks where the info is absorbed so quickly by so many people the moves are hard and fast? Yes, there is a lot of information and headlines that come out around these stocks and this generates movement. Regarding reactions to news, this does contribute to increased efficiency assuming its being done by knowledgeable participants. I think you are not getting that my qualm with all forms of EMH is with the statement that all available information again from any given combination of public and private info is incorporated into stock prices, which is a very strong statement. I think you believe the EMH and its varying forms to just be weak some information is incorporated, semistrong some more info is incorporated, strong all information is incorporated, which is a misinterpretation and not correct as Ive said multiple times. My only disagreement is that EMH does not preclude stocks from outperforming the market. If EMH were true, it would prevent investors from consistently outperforming on a risk adjusted basis which includes business risk, industry risk, stock volatility, as well as total portfolio risk and volatility holding 100 META is absolutely riskier than holding 100 SPY so should earn higher returns. I agree with the bolded part. My point is that a alpha generation does happen and b there is no way all public information, let alone all public AND private information is incorporated into security prices, hence my total disagreement with at least 2 of the 3 forms of EMH. Again, I think the entirety of disagreement is due to you not understanding what the EMH is explicitly claiming, on top of which not having real security selection experience leading to comments like efficiency just refers to how quickly new info is priced in, but has no influence on reaction size from this news.

I dont disagree with you on EMH by definition. In my first comment I was talking more colloquially that public info is absorbed extremely quickly in some markets US large cap for example and more slowly in other markets fixed income for example. Sure, it doesnt perfectly meet the exact definition of EMH, but most people dont care about the exact definition, they care about the general efficiency of markets. The only thing I fundamentally disagree with you on is rationality because there is no universal definition of a rational market. There is no one arbiter of rationality and the correct stock reaction to news. In your example if the stock is up 8 but your EPS estimates are up 15, theres many other investors who may have different views on EPS estimates and make them more or less bullish which raises the price by more or less than your expectation. They are still rational investors. Lastly, I get your point on META and Id agree if META jumped from 90 to 600 independently, however, it went from 380 to 90 and back up to 600. Of course if we choose trough to peak returns it looks irrational, but if we zoom out a bit the stock goes from 380 to 600 or 300 to 600 which is a 100 or lower returns in a 33.5 year period. Still high but not necessarily irrational depending on the fundamentals and expectations of the company. I do agree that the price action of META and others was questionable, however, I question if we can define that as an irrational market. I do also realize that me arguing the inability to define the rationality of the market in relation to EMH is an idiotic hill to die on because I dont even believe most of the assumption of EMH are true. I probably didnt clearly explain my views yesterday initially but dont disagree with you on much and I apologize for my snarkiness.

replies.text: At 7 I would put the money into the mortgage.
you should disclose your mortgage interest rate and if you are paying PMI or not, that is a big factor in any decision
If 100K towards a recast nets you 700 in saving per month then thats an 8.4 annual rate of return. What other investment would yield you those kinds of returns with virtually no risk? Id say do it

If youre looking for better cash flow and guaranteed savings, the mortgage recast is a great option.. But if youre comfortable with a bit of risk and want longterm growth, investing would likely yield better results. If you use the 100,000 to recast your mortgage, your monthly payment would drop from 3,368 to 2,178.87, which means youd save around 665 per month.. Over the life of your mortgage, this would also reduce your total interest payments by about 139,508.90 a nice chunk of change! If you decide to invest instead, and you can get a 7 average return over the next 10 years, your 100,000 could grow to around 196,715.14.. At this rate, your investment would give you a higher return compared to the interest youd save by recasting. But keep in mind, investments can fluctuate, while paying down your mortgage is a guaranteed return. Hope this helps

Maybe not a good comparison, but I made a move recently, house sold 25 over asking. We bought a house at half the price. At 49 Im working on financial independence. I can reinvest my profits and have zero debt. With my income I feel like killing off debt is my priority. That said my net worth is otherwise 2M. I have good savings. Im ready to wipe out the remaining debt.

If the market had just crashed, you would find me in the markets. Yes, the market is almost always near ATH, but were really juiced rn on valuations and elections produce uncertainty and such on and so forth. I dont think you could possibly regret freeing up 700 a month with a recast and cutting down the interest snowball on the mortgage, especially when the opportunity cost of investing in the market is not looking like an extremely attractive entry point.
You need to know the rate on the mortgage to know if its a good idea or not

If it really is a recast the IR is slightly less important but is still pretty relevant when calcd against returns of various securities fundamentally you could see this as 100k x mortgage rate vs 100k y market rate less taxes if you already have maxed 401k, SEP, IRA. To compare apples to apples not a great comparison but could ballpark compare what an annuity is getting compared to the interest rate on your current loan. Overall if your IR on your mortgage is anything like less than 4 id probably invest the 100k

If you like the house and want to stay in it and the area youre in, pay off the house. You just locked in 7 interest with no risk and no taxes. Now you have no house payment, so pay the 3,000 a month into your investments. Your investments will grow very fast, and now you have nothing to worry about. Market crashes? Who cares, you have a paid off house. Lose your job? Who cares, you have a paid off house and only need to come up with tax, utilities and food. One thing that people forget about when trying to optimize their money, is that when shit hits the fan, it hits the fan in every category. For example, in 2008 when the market crashed, housing crashed, stocks crashed 50, and unemployment was over 10, much more in certain fields. So one can say to oneself, in a crash, id just get richer, because id buy more. Well, during the crash is when you lose your job, your house goes down in value, so you dont want to sell and your mutual funds go down, so you sell into a loss. With a paid off house, you dont worry about any of this. John Goodman says it better than me.
Why not refinance? If you have good credit, I would think you could get into the mid 5 in an ARM loan with very little out of pocket that would be recouped in your interest savings quickly.

i did an extensive research and calculation a few months ago. At mortgage rate 6.875, sp 500 estimate return has high chance in2024 2025 beating the 6.785. but considering the tax impactbbenefit of debt and stocks , anything above 7.785 shall be paid off if your best alternative option is sp. so, 7 is on the fence, totally dependent on your risk appetite. I kept the 6.875 mortgage and used the money to do a 2 month investing challenggamble, and got a 1.5 gain from stock market, the cost of loan for 2 months is around 1.15. so i did marginally better from the market
Mortgage company websites often have little calculators telling you how many years putting x amount down in a lump sum towards principal would accelerate the pay off of the mortgage.
Theres many types of investing strategies and paying off the mortgage early would be good in very few circumstances. It would be better to invest.
Bitcoin. There is no second best.

Wouldnt even recast it. Just try and pay that principle down which will lower your paid interest. If rates go lower then Cash out refi and put it into another property or something else. FYI at those numbers your interest is a tax deduction, so that gets written off towards your income during tax season if you itemize.

Great breakdown, A mortgage recast offers guaranteed savings, while investing could lead to greater longterm gains. How do you feel about balancing both strategies for cash flow and growth?
as long as debt is less than return,u shall not worry about it

replies.text: historical data has shown that dividend paying stocks tended to outperform their non dividend paying counterparts. If dividends dont inherently add value, why is this the case? Life is not just about numbers. And the differences between dividend payments and stock buybacks involve a great deal more than math. Dividends are usually distributed in a systematic way, and cutting dividend payments is seen as a very bad sign. So, a dividend is in effect a statement by management that they believe the company can perform and continue to deliver into the future. Boeing is a case study. Prior to 1998 investment in new aircraft programs and the companys reputation was seen as a way to protect investors, and the dividend, well into the future. Post 1998 the Jack Welch school that came to control the company was focused on short term results and stock buybacks. The difference between Boeing today and what is called in the industry legacy Boeing is stark.

This is well documented but too often ignores the behavioral story. You touch on the misconceptions in your final paragraph. But perhaps they know themselves. By that I mean there are people for whom dividends have psychological benefits, meaning the ability to hold equity at all is improved by knowing the dividends are coming in.
In certain countries like Australia dividends have special treatment from a tax perspective also, which makes it an attractive component of total return.

What about people who are in distribution. Doesnt having some focus not total focus on quality stocks that are divided players help with cash flow during periods where sequence of return risk would be detrimental

Its a nice thought experiment, but youre taking it too far in your conclusions. Assumptions like management will always spend money in good faith to maximize earnings are useful if you want to make a world that is spreadsheetcompatible, but massively off the mark from the real world. In the real world management has incentives like getting the stock price to a certain number by a certain time to get a payout, future be damned. Creating unrealistic narratives about future earning to justify or increase PE ratios you know are excessive. Tech is a huge part of the SP500 and these problems are very common in tech. Around the dotcom crash this all got so bad that nobody could give out any dividends at all, for fear of demonstrating that they dont have endless golden geese lined up that the money would be better spent on. These days theyve gotten a little better about this and your Apple, Microsoft, and Google at least pay out a nominal dividend of like 0.51. Investors regularly get their money pissed up the wall like this in tech, when they would have been much better off just receiving it as a dividend than having tens of billions wasted on the metaverse with promises that all life would revolve around this concept in a few years, only to have them say actually never mind its all fake after a few years of stock options vesting at high valuations. Of course, were in the middle of a similar bubble with AI, so this all seems quaint now, but trust me, in a few years there will be a lot of people saying I wish they had just given me the money. So yeah, I like a small dividend, just to maintain a culture that this is my money they are playing with, and if they dont have a good use for it then Ill take it. A lot of this applies to share buybacks as well, although theyre prone to more bad incentives as they work through share price, so management is incentivized to do them even when the stock is already overvalued, and the personal incentives mentioned above etc.
Are dividend payouts on average less volatile than stock prices?

What you said is true. However dividend stocks typically fit in the Value category and they do have substantially different characteristics than growth stocks. Generally larger older companies with less volatility and more predictable cash flows or they wouldnt be paying dividends. So if you are trying to make the point that only younger faster growing growth stocks are the only thing you should invest in I would call you Wrong.

Part of the reason for dividends is they discipline management through requiring payouts and ensures they dont squander the companies cash. This is covered more in finance classes under treasury operations than capital structure. However, I think its a valid reason for dividends. True you may not want a fast growing company to pay dividends and instead invest in growth. However, most companies dont fall into that category and would likely waste extremely large investments. I guess you could make an argument for stock buybacks since they are more tax efficient but because they are expected at regular intervals they dont quite have the same ability to discipline management.

However, dividends themselves are an irrelevant criterion for investment selection. thats not what Modigliani and Miller claimed. Their research has been consistently distorted and misrepresented over the years. Note that MM didnt say that dividends were irrelevant they said, under their extremely narrow conditions, that dividend payout ratios should be irrelevant to the overall value of the firm. That is a specific finance claim, not a generalized disregard for dividend payments. It is not what MM said its what people now think they said. Theres a big difference. Daniel Peris, The Ownership Dividend Routledge, 2024
The payout of dividends is derisking. You could ride a growth stock all the way up and then all the way down with nothing to show for it.

I mean I appreciate the analysis but were splitting hairs when looking at the two most popular ETF, VOO any SP variant and SCHD. VOO 10 year fidelity stats 13.34 with 1.29 dividend SCHD 10 year fidelity stats 11.71 with 3.29 dividend The difference in total average return is 1.52, which is roughly the same difference between their dividend payout. The whole growthtotal returndividend drama is unnecessary and really only applies to high yield or yield max dividend products.

Empirical evidence, such as the drop in stock prices on the exdividend date, supports this theory. When a dividend is paid, the share price tends to decrease by the amount of the dividend, as cash leaving the company is reflected by a reduction in book value per share. Thats not just just a market tendency, its whats required to happen. All opening bids and offers are adjusted down by the amount of the dividend and any shareholders at the open are entitled to the dividend.

The Dividend Irrelevance Theory, proposed by Modigliani and Miller MM in 1961, asserts that dividend policy has no impact on a firms value or cost of capital in a frictionless market. So if this is false and dividends are better, dividends win. If this is true and dividends are the same....dividends also win because its the same thing. So whats the point of this discussion? The Dividend Irrelevance Theory, proposed by Modigliani and Miller MM in 1961, asserts that dividend policy has no impact on a firms value or cost of capital in a frictionless market. Under this theory, a companys value is determined solely by its earnings power and investment decisions, not by how it distributes its profits. Whether profits are retained or distributed, the firms underlying valuation remains the same. I highlighted the key phrase in that paragraph you wrote. Everything you say is true but investing is a personal situation driven game. During your accumulation phase you would be wrong to have any allocation other than a diversified portfolio that is spread between growth and value with some adjustment for whether we are in a Value or a Growth phase in the market. In the Early Accumulation phase you should be heavily invested in equities as you dont much care about down cycles as you have little money at risk. In the late accumulation phase you start to build in a strategy for up and down markets as you now have some principal to protect. In the Preretirement stage you start to worry more about beta and less about alpha particularly if you have done a good job of accumulation. In Retirement your goals are preservation and income, so less beta is more important than excess alpha unless you are late to the party. Assuming you have hit your goals, then joining rdividend and forgetting a growth allocation makes total sense. In that stage assuming a good number, you can use the dividends and leave the kids the equities at whatever value they may have when you are gone. Id actually argue that all else equal, dividends are actually a structural headwind to returns. As you point out, dividends are just a mandatory liquidation of a portion of the market cap of the company. Any investor who owns the stock via a basket e.g. an index fund investor who reinvests dividends is effectively going short the stock vs long the other stocks in the basket and actually reinvesting an even smaller portion than they would have otherwise because the dividend reduces the companys weight in the index. Extending the work of Koijen et al, this imbalanced flow should have a lasting price impact on the stock relative to the other constituents in excess of the fundamental change in the value of the companys assets

You would be knowledgable on a subject then, perhaps you can answer it. My understanding is, your actual numerical value of debt is essentially irrelevant provided you have the cashflow to make a lender comfortable. Is this ballpark accurate?

Correct. The most common way a lender will look at the quantum of debt they are willing to extend is a multiple on cash flow. So if you generate 100m in cash flow a year, a lender will most likely be willing to extend 300 400m or 3 to 4x cash flow. The primary reason being is a company will trade at some much higher multiple say 7 to 20 times depending on business so if youre only lent 3 to 4, you are safely inside a potential EV of the company. Secondarily, the lender wants to ensure you generate enough cash flow to cover the interest expense of the debt. There are other underwriting metholdogies though, multiple on recurring revenue or pure asset based lending against liquidation value of assets are two other common ones

I was her financial advisor while she lived independently. She was plenty savvy at the time and didnt have every penny with me. Her investments were conservative except being highly concentrated in Berkshire Hathaway, which frankly isnt actually a terrible concentration when you look at the underlying businesses they are in. Around 85 she gets introduced to some friends of her sister who lives on Long Island. These guys are selling private placement notes collateralized by structured settlements. They are based in Boca Raton but all the notes are shares of shell companies incorporated in the Caymans. These notes are paying 14 annually for 3 to 5 years each, this is around 2015 when rates are close to zero and commercial paper is paying 3.5. This shit is the most obvious red flag scam anyone with half a brain has ever seen. I drag Grandma into my office and have a sit down with two senior partners who have far more experience than me. We all go hard on laying out the case that shes getting scammed. All she sees are checks coming in and they never missed a payment ever for her sister! Shes unreachable in terms of convincing her shes playing with fire. The only thing I manage to get from her is to stop buying more of this garbage. Shes already in for 270k, total net worth around 750k at the time. Its a fucking horror show. Well you know what happens next. The company goes insolvent, the cofounder commits suicide by jumping off his boat in the Caribbean, the other bag holder cofounder get a DOJ indictment, and the whole shit show goes into corporate receivership under Florida law. The company was Seeman Holtz, feel free to Google it and see just how fucked all these long island Jews are for trusting those nice men who kept taking lonely widows out for dinners and calling them every week. Grandmas sister lost her husbands entire life savings of 5 million and is currently considering a reverse mortgage to pay her property taxes in a very expensive zip code. So yeah, by this time Ive left the financial advisory industry because I cant take sucking up to wealthy dumbasses anymore. Since Im no longer her fiduciary advisor I demand she set me up as a full durable POA if she wants my help. She admits defeat accepts reality and hands the keys over. It took losing over a quarter million to finally listen to my advice. Its not as simple as a poor old lady getting railroaded by an annuity but its the same story in the end. Hubris.

Schwabs estate department screwed up so badly while I was helping my mother deal with her husbands death. We had so many conference calls, local office meetings, open this account, close that account, fax this paper, point out they need to waive the fee for using their customer service phone system, because were on the phone on their local office and they dont keep a licensed broker in the office, so they initiated the call. I printed out what the IRS has regarding spousal inherited IRA, then they screwed up her step up of basis, etc. They sent her an apology gift, thanks, my mother really needed a table top wine bottle chiller. While one person on the phone is telling me why they wont send me a copy of a 1099, it arrives by email from the same department.

For what its worth, the reason your grandmother found herself in that situation is because she had to talk to representatives that probably had less than 3 months of experience and straight up gave her wrong information or lied to get her off the phone. By the time she got someone who knew what they were doing, if ever, enough time had passed that it could never be resolved through a simple phone call more than likely you needed a notarized letter. Unfortunately, the idiots she was talking to at THAT time were also probably new so they had no idea and just said oops I feel sorry for you but nothing I can do. The incompetence is astronomical among the phone representatives and for good reason Vanguard targets foolish undergrads that have no idea what they are getting into AND they pay below average. So when their hires find out they are literally just a phone farm and they are getting paid less than the industry for it, they leave, causing massive turnover and requiring Vanguard to get more dogshit people. Because the turnover is so high, no one knows what they are doing but still have to meet metrics so they just lie to get people off the phones. By default, the clients get pissed and take it out on the new reps that have no idea what they are doing causing them to leave making vanguard hire more inexperienced people further pissing off their clients and so on. Unfortunately, Vanguard doesnt give two shits and a shake because their retail arm for people under 5MM doesnt make them that much money. Their power comes from their institutional side and index retirement funds. As a retail investor, youre a drop in the bucket unless youre handing over 5MM to their Personal Advisor Services.
The complaint doesnt go to that associate, it gets routed to the firms compliance department, and several levels of the operations department work to verify the correct form is sent out this time.

I agree with this. You dont threaten a complaint. You just file it. Those front end reps are really limited as to what they can do. Even when they hear the words...we are filing a complaint...there is still nothing they can do. This is the lesson to be learned. We waited for months for Vanguard to resolve something. 7 months all up and I dont believe a resolution was ever going to come. After 2 or 3 phone calls, just file the complaint. Keep in mind that it if hasnt been fixed in 23 calls, its unlikely it will be. And your time is worth something. Spending 30 hours over a year to get something resolved is ridiculous. You dont get paid to resolve issues with VG. Value your time.

Unfortunately the only physical offices near me are Edward Jones. Not my first choice, but once youve spent 15 or so phone calls over an hour long each then you just want to pull your hair out and be done with it all lol.

replies.text: Lets take a step back. Most of the comments here are not accurate. The ticker BMWYY has never been listed. It is an OTC ADR. OTC means overthecounter and its considered unlisted. It appears to have been a sponsored ADR A depository bank created the product on the OTC and its sponsored by the company. In this particular case they weree depository receipts from BNY. Occasionally, the depository or the sponsor may terminate the ADR for various reasons. A termination notice would have been disclosed. In your case see attached If you did not sell out your position before the termination issuance on 927 you will have to go through the liquidation process. The last day to trade BMWYY was 926. Your investment is NOT worthless It should be approximately USD20ish or more per share. When an ADR terminates normally you have a choice to get the shares and deposit into a local custodian in this case you need a German brokerage account or your broker can try to liquidate it for you and get you cash value back assuming your broker offers those services. But there is a fee to do that because of the bookeeping, currency risk, etc. involved thats probably what the 300 is for. This is why investing in unlisted ADRs and OTC securities are considered riskier if you dont monitor your investments. edit fwiw in case anyone else cares. When you invest in unlisted ADRs the 2 major depository banks providing DR services are BNYMellon and Citi. BNYMellon has some better monitoring capabilities and it can be found here Termination notices like the one for OPs BMWYY look like this The termination notice provides options for ADS holders. In this particular case, the depository plans to create an unsponsored ADR so that sponsored ADR holders could transfer their holdings to the new security. An unsponsored ADR means that BMW is not associated with the actual ADR anymore.
What Im getting from this post is that BMW investors are just as knowledgeable about investing as BMW drivers are about driving

In Canada just dealt with TD Waterhouse. 3 options Transfer to non sponsored full swap. Transfer to sponsored at .333 value per share owned Liquidate at who knows what sale price Needed to decide by 1026 I chose number 2 not sure if right call or not

Robinhood announced this Wait until cash liquidation after October 29, 2024. If you decide to do nothing, BNY Mellon may sell the underlying foreign shares. Robinhood in that case will surrender your ADRs to the depository in exchange for cash that will be distributed to you at some point after October 29, 2024. Youll receive the net of proceeds minus any fees and tax withholding charged by the depository. These fees are not charged by Robinhood

replies.text: Have you considered simply combining VOOIJRIJH into VTI or ITOT or SCHB? These 3 funds are all total US market style. Theyll hold all 3 market cap segments at their respective weights. International Exposure? Ive heard mixed advice about adding international stocks. Im currently 100 U.S.focused. Is that okay for a Roth IRA, or should I be looking to diversify more globally? US only is single country risk, which is an uncompensated risk one that doesnt bring higher expected long term returns. Uncompensated risk should be avoided whenever possible. Compensated vs uncompensated risk Bold mine Uncompensated risk is very different it is the risk specific to an individual company, sector, or country. Many people try to use the excuse that SP 500 companies do lots of business overseas, but that isnt the international coverage that actually matters. Companies will act more like the market of their home country, so foreign revenue isnt the international exposure that actually matters The purpose of the international holdings is to be covered during the orange periods of the graph here Plus thats true of large companies in most countries. There are many market sectors where foreign companies are some of the key players and do lots of business within the US, but that doesnt mean we can go 100 IXUS. Going global can both help with returns and volatility.

replies.text: Look at the 1099DIV instructions. Specifically Box 1a and Box 2a In short, your broker should report it in a way that your tax software can handle it properly since Box 1a will include shortterm capital gain distribution and Box 2a will only contain long term capital gains distributions. The website for the ETF specified that the distribution was for both short and long term capital gains in particular amounts.
But Box 1a is Ordinary dividends, not shortterm capitalgain. BOXX has conveyed to its investors that this a shortterm gain, and not Ordinary dividends.

I stand by what I wrote. Shortterm capital gains distributions from ETF and Mutual funds are included in the ordinary dividends Box 1a. Long term capital gains distributions are included in Box 2a. This means that realized capital losses cant be deducted directly against shortterm capital gains distributions from ETFs, except to the extent that 3000 against ordinary income each year can be deducted.

replies.text: Demonstrate value. This is actually not that hard, if you just post publicly ideally on a platform you cant subsequently go in and edit, the live trades your system proposes and then post evidence of the profits those trades generate you could quite quickly build up evidence that you have successfully found a valuable edge on the market. The problem wont be getting the phone number of a guy at a hedge fund, the problem will be that your system probably doesnt actually offer an edge most dont.
You go to college, you get a degree in finance, you start working in finance, you make some contacts, and you talk to them about your ideas until one of them takes you seriously.
If your system works all you have to do is keep investing all your money and in no time youll be rich and famous. Just what no one has ever done before predicting stocks.

Youll probably get a bunch of derisive answers, but seriously, youll need a track record. Ideas are only as valuable as their execution, and a good idea is indistinguishable from a bad idea before its tried out. If theres a way you can test your outcome for statistical significance, then so much the better. In the meantime, dont worry about the stage of reaching out since your probability of failure is so high. Yes, my answer would be incomplete without the part that everyone else is going to say. The EMH isnt perfect, but the markets are certainly efficient enough to make daytoday movements pretty much a random walk. So you have to consider the very strong likelihood that youre unintentionally fooling yourself. EDIT given your likelihood of failure, I strongly, strongly, strongly recommend paper trading before real money trading.

I was considering that as well. Do you have any suggestions for a reputable platform where I can post my trades in a way that prevents any editing afterward, to establish proof of my edge? One approach could be to post on a website and then archive it, or perhaps even embed my trades in a blockchain transaction to verify them later. Im also thinking about sending emails to trading firms with my predicted market timings for the next four months, then following up after theyve seen the results for themselves.

Neither of those sentences is true. If the strategy produces a good 3 alpha relative to the SP 500, then it would be invaluable, but barely better for an individual than investing in VOO. And tons of people made systems that worked, like the late great Jim Simons.

I completely understand the importance of having a solid track record. Over the past six months, Ive tested my strategy and made a profit through investment. Initially, I considered using my strategy for day trading too to achieve huge gains on my own, but later Ive realized its more suited for longerterm investments rather than day trading. Going forward, I plan to keep a detailed track of my trades over a longer period and share my live trades with others to demonstrate that I do have an edge. I appreciate your advice and will be careful to ensure that I build a solid record.
Stop gambling your money away, dreamer.

Ok, a little delayed response, but this is what I learned. The shares are held by a global custodian that Schwab uses didnt get a specific name. They are able to transfer those stocks to Byrons registry through boardroom nominee company that Byron uses. I was told that if I take the shares off Schwab, that it would be likely impossible to get a broker to touch them if I wanted to ever sell. This is due there are laws in place that make it hard for big broker companies to sell stocks under 5.00 that are removed like this. Not sure if that is a scare tactic or what, but good to know. I spoke directly with a broker that deals with foreign transactions, rather than my first attempt getting tossed from department to department.

Thanks for coming back to provide an update. It does make sense. Not sure if that is a scare tactic.... And yes the company is effectively going private and isnt listed on the ASX you wont be able to find a retail broker to provide a transaction because there is no market. There are private placement brokers but the commission structure is usually about 45 and those types of brokers dont do small transactions.

By them you contacted the share registry company? And thats what they said? Or do you mean that you contacted the Bryron Energy. I do not know if it would be held in street name unless it is DTCC eligible but thats just a guess And unfortunately OTC Markets removes the F share information once a stock is no longer available so I cant find much info. And I dont really know that much about how F shares are transacted. If this was an unsponsored ADR you could contact the depository the depository will usually have a process to handle it. But the ticker implies its an F share. But from what I have seen in the past with F shares the shareholder lists is based on the local market see FAQ here I guess you could always call Schwab again and ask for their OTC support. If you just spoke with a firstline customer support person they may not know much.

I talked to a broker at Schwab, he seemed like he knew a little more than the front line but didnt mention anything abut F shares or ADRs. I dont think based on the ticker symbol that it is an ADR. The F usually means that its a foreign ordinary. Whatwho is the depository? If it was an ADR there would have been a bank in the US that would be buying the shares and and offering it as a receipt. The bank is the depository. Usually when there is a corporate action the depository would publish a process for dealing with the corporate action. A foreign ordinary is basically what it sounds like. You are actually buying the shares through a dealer over the counter of the actual shares that list on the ASX. But I do not know much about the custody process for F shares. The FAQ that I linked implies that it may be held in the local market which would be in Australia. contacted Byron and that was the response. Ok yeah that kinda makes sense. The terminology used in Australia is different than in the US so I think that may be synonymous with custodian. to a broker at Schwab Try calling again different brokers have different levels of knowledge. The people at a brokerage that process corporate actions are probably not brokers.

replies.text: Your comments dont really make sense. A circuit breaker is an exchange facility. And its not some random person that makes a decision to pause trading. Your point about afterhours makes no sense either. Its called afterhours because the exchanges are closed. What would circuit breakers have to do with that?

An official circuit breaker is whats stated in the definition above, which by nature is an externality of the market in real application. Upon reopening of trades shortly before close, positions have already then been made to execute, in favor of funds as many times retail is unable to set up trades to execute before closing again shortly after. This is an unnecessary interruption when market wide, only occurring when falling under SEC guidelines, in other cases, just as stock by stock circuit breakers are used to halt the trades of specific stocks, select exchanges halt trading, but not all exchanges creating a wildly unlevel market temporarily. I urge you to read the ENTIRE writup again, as Im restating whats been already written. You appear to possibly have missed some of the key inconsistencies of circuit breakers by exchanges when not falling under the official guidelines.

Your post wasnt particularly very interesting or compelling. And I dont necessarily agree with some of your conclusions. Do you have direct market microstructure experience by working with or at a broker or exchange, etc.? If not it would be more helpful if you cited some actual studies or data to validate your thesis. Tbh I only commented because I was wondering if you are a bot.

I believe you still dont understand the instances of exchanges halting trades unofficially when not under guidelines of an official breaker, therefore does not have available data to provide other than what is observable by price action in real time when the next one happens.
Working for a broker or exchange in your eyes is the only form of credibility regardless of market understanding ? If thats the case many economists if not the majority of them are not credible.
Ahh the NBER paper that the article mentions looks interesting. Thanks. Ill check that out.

Nah I was just making a point that I dont know what your background is and I dont generally believe random stuff that I read on social media. And most economist dont care about market microstructure. But if you can cite some helpful studies Im usually more interested in reading those. I can understand that there will be criticism about the use of circuit breakers. There will always be pros and cons.

Apple doesnt really sell its marketing data. Think more aligned to you play words with friends. When words with friends is ready to show an ad, they reach out to their ad platform, say AppLovin, to hey give me an ad for this user. AppLovin reaches out to 100s of parties that theres user X with iPhone 16 in roughly this geo area interested in an ad, give me your bid. This type of ad auction leads to some identifiable info being shared to many parties. This is sometimes sold as bulk datasets. You can then use that dataset to get a rough idea on where the person was. Then you got the more shady places and more shady apps that literally log your gps location and WiFi networks nearby. These shadier companies will sell this dataset for money. All this marketing data can then be used to roughly know where everyone in your household is going to. For example if I know you work at a Starbucks, and I see a phone to from your house to Starbucks then back every Monday through Friday for roughly 95. I know that phone Id belongs to you. Can them figure out where else you are traveling to.

replies.text: How does receiving dividends, pay taxes, then contribute to your IRA make more money than buying that asset in the IRA and keeping the dividends inside? Where does the extra money come from?
You would make more money in the long run just buying VOO instead of

Just think of dividends as a forced sale of the stock. If I have a single share of a 100 stock and get a 1 dividend now have 1 taxed dollar and a 99 share of stock. I reinvest that 1 into that stock. I now have 100 worth of stock. Nothing happened, but I get to pay taxes on 1. Would you sell stock every month just to reinvest into that same stock immediately to DVA? No, that would be insane.
Dividends arent free money, the share price drops by the distribution amount. Theyre a neutral event at best. Theyre already a part of total return.

All that really matters is if the fund or company you invest in outperforms the SP500. You can replace jepidividend fund with any other stock and the answer remains the same. They arent going to create extra cash in your Roth any more than more shares of VOO will. Investing half in JEPI instead of VOO may yield a better return, or it may not. That depends on the performance of the fund and of the SP. If your question is, should you pick companiesfunds to try to beat the SP, the answer depends on your risk tolerance, willingness to research and actively manage your Roth, and so on. Its certainly possible. I think certain dividend funds are almost sure to perform worse, like SCHD, which values lower volatility and a stable income source more than growth. Others, like certain REITs, have historically outperformed the SP and may continue to do so.

Invest 3050 of yearly contribution into something such as JEPI or another high income dividend ETF 1. Use monthly quarterly dividend payments to by more VOO or VTI, any etf, etc Why would you do this instead of just buying 100 VOOVTI? the dividends are not free money, they are a functionally a forced sale of stock. This strategy would just move value from one fund to another.
It wont grow faster.

This strategy does not make sense. From just square one the SP will likely give you greater total return than any of these dividend ETFs. You would rather have everything in your roth, invested in the highest returning ETF which will be an index oriented ETF ideally tracking SP 500 or US stock market. The dividend is counted as part of total return. If you were to compare a dividend etf yielding 5 and total return of 6 versus SP total return of 7 you are comparing 6 vs. 7. The dividend is not extra money. Reinvesting the dividend is the same as remaining invested in an equal returning etf without dividends. Semiirrelevant, but you will also be receiving some dividend through any indexoriented strategy. If this is some sort of account switching shenanigans... if you were to invest outside of your roth and transfer in the dividend yield, you are paying unnecessary taxes and SIGNIFICANTLY hurting your return. Example with 100, a 10 dividend, 30 tax You receive 100 You invest it in a dividend ETF yielding 10 One year later, you have collected 10 in dividends and paid 3 in tax, net transfer or gain of 7 to Roth Alternatively, if you had just put that into the SP in your roth to begin with call it 10 return... you would simply have a gain of 10 in the account. No tax. Lots of mental gymnastics I really dont follow the bottom line is there is no hack for investing greater than your contribution limit. If you want to maximize your roth account, simply transfer in the max contribution and invest within the roth within the highest returning asset you can. from a risk return basis, you should just be doing market indices. Generally 7030 US and global exUS is recommended, although doing all US certainly is acceptable as well.

JEPI underperforms the nasdaq it sells covered calls on. Theres at least a mild argument to SCHD in terms of saying you want to tilt way far away from more volatile tech companies which the market is full of rn.

You need 2 accounts. Your 401k traditional or Roth where you speculate and gamble. You need a 2nd account for your emergency fund. While the past was 6 months was enough Im not convinced. We worked our emergency fund to be enough to bridge me to retirement in 7 years. I turn 60 later this year. That money is in TBIL and CLIP ETFs 5.25 and supposedly federal tax exempt but IDK as this is our first year in those ETFs. While we have done well in our gambling 401k funds we are also generating a healthy income every month in the ETFs that is getting reinvested. Yes, we may be leaving a lot of money on the table but compared to our 401k probably not. And it is guaranteed to not lose principal which is the ultimate goal for our emergency fund.

Your plans are good. Now knowing your age and investments ahead of you, I dont recommend JPEI and JPEQ so much or if at all for you at this stage. The reason is your investment time horizon is much further than mine now in retirement, youd be foregoing major upside potential. You could instead invest SCHD dividends in future VOO etc. Id suggest this option you suggested, if it was my proposed VOO investment money Wait and see if we have perhaps a 5 correction and then dca. However, SP .SPX was recent highs 5661 on 716, and it was 5346 on 82, 5.5 correction. So, youre at your 5. But is it done declining? My analysis says likely not. Look at this chart See top, middle, and bottom chart sections. Notice in particular the MACD chart at bottom, red and black curves. In short, MACD is a buy sell pressure indicator with ascending curves above zero midline buy, descending below dont buy. I observe both red and black MACD curves plunging, well below zero, black below red and descending faster, no upcurve in sight. Combine this with price action center chart strongly down at most recent far right. This tells me all the decline is not priced in yet and more SP carnage to come in next daysweeks. If I was in your position, Id stay in SPAXX and watch this chart until MACD trend reverses, black surpasses red, and charges toward getting above the zero line. Look at the chart again Tuesday, compare to last Friday. Yes, this is called timing the market. Can save you money on your basisentry point of a lump investment if you know what youre doing. You wont hit it exactly, but you wont buy too soon. This impacts your VOO and possibly SCHD entry timing., but you can look at their individual charts at the link above for details on them specifically. Disclaimer I can be wrong. Not financial advice, just what Id do. As always, time in the market beats timing the market. If this doesnt pay off for you in a few days you might want to reconsiderdisregard and plunge. You might want to consider staying invested in what you choose and adding to it DCA in the future to maximize your yields. Jumping around to various hot ETFs of the day is not wise IMHO in the long run.

removed

Its not a Backdoor conversion, now. Once the funds have any earnings, the conversion is pro rata taxable. The point of Backdoor is to make a non deductible contribution and immediately convert it. That way, the receiving Trad IRA account has only Basis and no tax is owed at conversion. So, yes, waiting was not a good idea. Youll report this with your 2024 1040.
Yes, converting after the calendar year

Summary Eli Lilly LLY has exhibited robust revenue growth and profitability over the past four years, with Total Revenue and Operating Income showing consistent upward trends. However, challenges in managing cash flow, increasing debt levels, and low liquidity ratios pose risks to the companys financial health. Despite facing operational, regulatory, macroeconomic, competitive, technological, and ESG risks, LLY remains a key player in the pharmaceutical industry with opportunities for growth through innovation and expansion. Investors should carefully consider these factors in their investment decisions. Key Financial Insights Strong revenue growth from 24.54 billion in 2020 to 34.12 billion in 2023, representing a 39 increase. Healthy profitability margins with Gross Profit margin at 79.2 and Net Profit Margin at 15.3. Total Assets increasing steadily to 64.01 billion in 2023, reflecting a strong asset base expansion. Focus on revenue diversification, cost optimization, and debt reduction for sustained growth. Operational efficiency improvements and innovation investments are crucial for longterm success. Risk Factors High debt levels with Net Debt growing from 12.94 billion in 2020 to 22.41 billion in 2023. Negative Free Cash Flow in 2023 signaling liquidity challenges. Low liquidity ratios Current Ratio 0.94, Quick Ratio 0.92 indicating potential cash flow constraints. Operational, regulatory, macroeconomic, competitive, technological, and ESG risks impacting financial performance. Moderate Value at Risk VaR of 0.45 pointing to a moderate level of risk associated with investing in LLY. Conclusion Given the companys strong revenue growth and profitability trends, coupled with the risks posed by cash flow management and debt levels, investors should exercise caution. A hold recommendation is advisable at this juncture, allowing for further monitoring of operational improvements and debt reduction strategies to better gauge the companys longterm financial stability and growth potential.

5g from space works by using very large phased arrays that use beam forming to pick up signal from cellphones and low power devices. For the frequencies AST partners up with MNO around the world to use their spectrum. The FCC is actually finalizing the framework for spectrum reuse from space in the US, called SCS supplemental coverage from space. So AST does not have to acquire spectrum or spectrum rights. AST is partnered up with ATT and Verizon in the US for spectrum reuse. They have memorandum of understanding with over 40 other mobile network operators worldwide

Guys, if you are new to this sector, please read this message as a bit of advice from someone who has been in this investment since 2019. It is a volatile sector. Expect big drops of 20 in mid cap stocks and even more in small caps. Within a week. This happens also for the upside like we see this month for a lot of the U equities. That said, there is unbelievable valuation and immense upside to many uranium juniors and business focused on the fuel cycle enrichment etc. This sector moves at a glacial speed, and many stocks do get ahead of themselves. Do lots of homework on companies that are developers of mines. The only producers that need to be considered for a newbie is Cameco, Uranium energy Corp, boss energy and energy fuels. If you want more then look at Sprotts Uranium information on their website. Dont listen to hype on YouTube, X, and other sources. Its a great opportunity to buy a non fungible, scarce and undervalued commodity, but dont expect to make life changing money if you consider yourself an average investor, much of the easy money has been made already in the sitting and waiting. Now is the time to look for value, performance and the companies that are actually going to be able to mine this resources at significant quantities well into the future. Alongside the companies involved in the other services in the sector. This bull market is not a flash in the pan. This time for the nuclear industry, its game on.

The uranium market is already seeing a mix of tight supply and rising demand for nuclear energy, especially as countries push for clean energy solutions. Kazakhstans recent production cuts and the U.S. banning Russianenriched uranium are only going to add more pressure to an already constrained market. On top of that, demand for uranium is expected to grow as China and other nations continue to build nuclear reactors. Prices have been fluctuating, but many experts believe they will rise again due to these supply and demand dynamics. Whats also interesting is how big tech companies are now getting involved. Microsoft recently signed a deal to revive the Three Mile Island nuclear plant to power its data centers, while Oracle is building small modular reactors SMRs to fuel its AI data centers. These reactors are expected to deliver over 1 gigawatt of electricity, showing just how critical energy demand has become in powering AI growth. This could lead to even higher demand.

Still waiting for liquid fluoride thorium reactor LFTR to come online. These can convert Thorium232 into Thorium233. This decays into Protactinium233, which further decays into Uranium233. Protactinium233 can be removed from the liquid salt of a tworegion MSR by reductive extraction into liquid bismuth. Basically a breeder reactor that uses a cheaper and more abundant fuel source. This style of reactor was designed in the 1950s and I honestly believe the main reason this hasnt been developed further is more due to proliferation risks than cost or feasibility. Since the Protactinium233 can be extracted rather easily and would be of high concentration, it would reduce a lot of the work needed to make a nuclear weapon. Mainly removal of neutron emitters and other purification steps to get to 95 purity of Uranium233. Uranium233 is a fissile isotope.

TL,DR from ChatGPT Summary Uranium Market Report Price Trends Since 2020, uranium prices have surged from 21lb to 106lb in February 2024, currently stabilizing at 83lb. The report suggests that this increase is only the beginning, with further growth expected. Uranium Overview Uranium is a naturally occurring radioactive metal, primarily used for nuclear energy. The key isotopes are U238 used in military applications and U235 used to fuel nuclear reactors. U235 is particularly efficient, with one kilogram producing energy equivalent to over 3 million pounds of coal. HALEU and Enrichment Highassay lowenriched uranium HALEU is critical for advanced nuclear reactors. The U.S. is investing in domestic HALEU production to reduce reliance on imports, especially from Russia, which controls a significant portion of global enrichment capacity. The U.S. has started producing HALEU domestically, supported by government initiatives. Supply Challenges Uranium supply is tightening due to depleted inventories and underinvestment in mining. Mines are expensive and slow to develop, often taking 1015 years to become operational. The market is shifting to rely more on primary mining as secondary supplies dwindle. Primary production is forecasted to decrease by 30 by 2035, highlighting a potential supply gap. Demand Growth The U.S., China, and France account for 58 of global uranium demand. As of 2024, there are 440 operating reactors worldwide, with many more planned. The World Nuclear Association predicts a 28 increase in demand from 20232030 and a 51 rise from 20312040, driven by global clean energy goals. Global Production Kazakhstan is the leading producer, supplying 43 of global uranium. However, production cuts due to delays and shortages could put further pressure on prices. The U.S. has also increased its domestic uranium production in 2024, signaling a shift toward selfreliance. Investment Insights The report suggests that mining companies are wellpositioned to benefit from rising uranium prices. Companies like Cameco, NexGen Energy, and ETFs such as URNM and NUKZ are highlighted as investment opportunities. Big tech companies like Amazon and Google are also investing in nuclear energy, emphasizing the growing interest in this sector. Conclusion The report anticipates a bullish market for uranium due to increasing demand and limited supply. With countries seeking clean energy and reducing carbon emissions, uraniums role as a key energy source is set to grow, potentially driving prices to unprecedented levels. no because unlike with other forms of fuel, uranium costs are a tiny portion of the overall cost of building and operating a reactor. the majority of the cost is the upfront capex for building the reactor 10s of billions for big multireactor plants. then, the marginal cost of loading them with reactor is almost negligible in comparison. due to how expensive reactors are to build, countries cant afford to let then sit idle regardless of uranium prices. It was calculated that 700lbs is the cutoff at which point it becomes uneconomical to keep running the reactors. this is 8x the current price. due to these factors, uranium supply is priceinelastic

Global turnover in U is pretty large but a rather small share of it ever meaningfully sees the market. The industry is vertically integrated to an incredibly high degree. A given mine might be in Canada, but it is owned by a consortium of utilities that ultimately use the metal and the price is just an exercise in accounting, the actual cost to the utilities being their share of the wages and operation costs of the mine, because while they might Buy the U, that amounts to taking money out of their left pocket and putting it into the right one. This means that mines opening up or closing that do sell on the open U market can swing the price like mad. It doesnt matter to most of the industry.

The two books I mentioned inspired me to forge my own trading style, I dont think they even fit majority of traders styles. If I have to give one advice about trading, the one I will give is to manage risk and stay in the game. When you get experienced enough, there will always be times you have high degree of certainty, and the trade will work almost perfectly. You never want to run out of bullets when that kind of situation happens, and I can assure you, they will happen, way more than what we expect actually. TIGR is an outlier on the speed and size of the gain, but in terms of degree of certainty, it only ranks slightly above average for me. A lot of my winners were traded with deeper research and confidence, although the percentage return is not as dramatic, plus most of the time, I prefer using stocks only rather than a mixture or pure options.

Yeah right bro. China stocks have massively, MASSIVELY underperformed their GDP growth. Why is that? Corruption. The reason people dont pile money into Chinese companies is because a significant portion of the profits in those companies are extracted by insiders. Whether thats public or private insiders doesnt matter, and in China theyre often the same thing. Since 1995, the SSEC has basically 5Xed. Meanwhile, their GDP went up about 21X. At least in real estate, people know they have a real asset. Not just a piece of paper that says you own part of a company. And you have to depend that this company is providing real financial statements, not hiring their brothers concrete company at 10X market value to redo their parking lot every month. Equity ownership can only provide excess returns if the businesses are run transparently. The default human behavior in most places is corruption. Its incredibly easy, and many times impossible to really tell. Especially at higher levels. But how can we expect a country like China, where corruption is firmly embedded in publicprivate sector, to suddenly flush it out? Xi can say or do whatever he wants. Smart money knows to stay away from China. Sure, you can allocate a small portion of a portfolio. But smart money knows its a risky play. Smart money is focused on capital preservation. They arent going to spray and pray that China has fixed their bullshit. If you wanna spray and pray, might as well just go buy BTC. At least you know the rules, and they are visible to everyone. Not the case with China and many other countries with rampant corruption.

The U.S. Federal Aviation Administration FAA is preparing to release a crucial regulation that will help pave the way for the commercialization of eVTOL aircraft in the U.S., according to Christopher Coes, acting under secretary of transportation for policy at the U.S. Department of Transportation. Speaking at Honeywells Advanced Air Mobility AAM Summit on Sept. 19, Coes announced that the final special federal aviation regulation SFAR for poweredlift pilot certification and operations is expected to be published in the next month.

Update 2 This information is huge regarding final SFAR FAA Rule The U.S. Federal Aviation Administration FAA is preparing to release a crucial regulation that will help pave the way for the commercialization of eVTOL aircraft in the U.S., according to Christopher Coes, acting under secretary of transportation for policy at the U.S. Department of Transportation. Speaking at Honeywells Advanced Air Mobility AAM Summit on Sept. 19, Coes announced that the final special federal aviation regulation SFAR for poweredlift pilot certification and operations is expected to be published in the next month. I think youll see it is quite responsive to industry comments, Coes told attendees. It will come well ahead of certifications that the FAA is working very hard with our manufacturers. The SFAR was a hot topic at last years summit, where the draft version faced considerable criticism. Industry concerns focused on the certification process for pilots, the requirement for dual flight controls, energy reserves for electric aircraft, and flight simulation training devices. Many in the industry felt the rules governing pilot certification and operations of a novel technology like poweredlift eVTOLs should be modernized to reflect the unique aspects of electrification and range. However, at this years summit, the mood had shifted toward cautious optimism for the release of the final SFAR. Theres great anticipation for the rule, which were told is coming in just a few weeks, said Kristie Greco Johnson, senior vice president of government affairs with the National Business Aviation Association NBAA. If the FAA can deliver the rule in just a few short weeks, itll be a major accomplishment for the agency. While Coes contends the final SFAR will be released in the next month, the FAA technically has until Dec. 16 to finalize the regulation, according to the FAA reauthorizaton bill. The same bill also mandated that a notice of proposed rulemaking NPRM for unmanned aerial systems UAS operating beyond visual line of sight BVLOS be issued by Sept. 16. However, the FAA missed that deadline, raising concerns about the SFARs timely release. There is broad consensus that the U.S. faces stiff competition from global players to lead in AAM. With first movers like Joby Aviation and Archer Aviation aiming for a 2025 commercialization of eVTOLs, the pressure is on the FAA to meet expectations.
