Im not sure what you mean by unregulated. Why would you think this business reverses? They have the largest market share for the app market. Google buys from them for example. This business has been growing every quarter for many years. They do rely on google and apple app stores which is a clear negative but given pressure from regulators in Europe and US wa potential justice department breakup of google, they wont F with Applovin their hands tied and cant be viewed as monopolistic. IMO this is a unique time where there is a window for Applovin to become much bigger. In terms of insider selling, a lot of these sales are for tax net settling of shares. But yes many others have been outright selling. CEO still owns billions of stock and many insiders still own large amount of shares relative to what they sold. KKR doesnt count, they 10x their money and their fund vintage was ending, so they needed to sell. You can also make same argument for META or NVDA, ton of insider selling there. Also the valuation isnt even close to bloated. They report GAAP earnings but if you add back amortization and stock based comp like every peer does, they are trading low 20s PE for a business growing 20 wvery high incremental margins. Thats very inexpensive in this market.

What I mean by unregulated is the distinct way that they facilitate the collection of invaluable private data and improve targeting by doing so....which is the lions share of the value. I really do like the notion that we live in a time where an upstart like Applovin could forge their own market share amidst the big dogs. I will always be FOR that...however the behavior of the founders and csuite does not reflect a solid alignment with this end goal. They would not sap billions from the coffers at their first opportunity, when their company may need all the help and good will that it can get over the coming quarters. I do not believe that large funds give an eff about this company beyond the extent to which they can accumulate and distribute shares over and over again, kinda like the apparent behavior of the principals of the company. Btw I really truly do appreciate you chiming in. This is the type of discussion that needs to openly take place!

I think they operate within the required rules the app stores set on them. I dont think there is anything nefarious going on. In fact it appears they are a good actor. I pressed info on one of their ads and this came up.... Shows that you can opt out of any of their advertisements and request them not to track you. I rarely see advertising companies showcasing that. Big funds do care. Thats why the stock is moving because you have institutional buying this up. Its also big enough to be added to SP 500 so its just a matter of time.

If you look at their SDK, the beauty of it becomes quite clear. It is on the advertiser to promise to collect and make proper use of the data....down to the age and precise location. You have full access to it, you need to pass a variable to us saying that you have been given permission by the user to use it, and we trust you. With or without the actual consent, it can be used. There is no true protection....just a loose legal framework to cover their ass. Ai.....blah, blah, blah.....THIS is the secret sauce. Similar to the dilution by vesting disclaimer and clawback policy found buried in their quarterlies only after facing legal action from shareholders it is the same pattern.....smoke...meet mirrors. All good things must come to an end..... This is just a public service announcement. I no longer have a horse in this race. If this DD saves one person from getting burned....it was totally worth it.

The deadline for 10K was missed and they are late. Now they have to file a 12b25 form with the SEC, and they said they would do it by the end of today. If they file it, they will automatically be granted a 15 day extension for 10K, and if the filing is made within the extension period, it will be deemed by SEC as to have been filed on time and no further action is taken by the SEC. Itll be very interesting if they miss it again, and even if they dont, what reason for delay will they provide this time, since its not their first time theyre filing a 12b25, and what else will be shown in the form. Regardless, the timing of getting crisis management veteran on board and book cooking allegations dont bode well. This is something one could expect from a SPAC, not a SP listed company.

If I may l link you an article Nobody would want to get famous the way Steve Altemus got famous. It was in 2003 that Altemuss name first became widely known, back when he was working for NASA in the human spaceflight division. On Feb. 1 of that year, the space agency was shaken to its roots, after the space shuttle Columbia disintegrated on reentry, claiming the lives of its sevenperson crew. Altemus was put in charge of the forensic examination following the tragedy, assembling the 85,000 pieces of Columbia debris to help determine the cause of the accident. He did his job wellso well that the surviving three shuttles were able to fly without incident for eight and a half more years before their retirement in the summer of 2011. There is no team in the world better suited for this task.

I am not employed by Intuitive Machines.

They have a couple of businesses. 1 They have a spaceship that goes to the moon on a schedule. Private companies and other countries pay to put their payload on their ship to be sent to the moon. Theyre essentially providing a bus service to deliver your stuff to the moon. 2 Theyre building a network of satellites around the moon, so you can keep radio contact around the clock with people or devices and machines on the moon. This is essentially the NSNS contract thats pumping the price now. If anybody needs to communicate with their payload or astronauts on the moon, they can pay to use the satellites there, like a telco service. 3 Theyre building larger moon lander, to deliver up to 1.5 tonnes payload. They also planning to continue developing the VIPER moon rover by NASA and deliver it through this Lander. So future companies and other countries can pay LUNR to deliver vehicles and heavier payloads to the moon. 4 Theyre developing navigation system for US military satellites, they won the contract recently. 5 There is a plan to build a space station to orbit the moon, so we can send astronauts there like a pitstop, before they continue their journey to Mars. Thats one of NASAs long term plan and Artemis project. As of now, they no longer have debts and theyre profitable. The company only went listed last year in 2023, so were actually in the very early stages like how Amazon started. This could huge in the future, like a decade from now when space is the next frontier.

1. High Expectations Create Downside Risk As mentioned earlier, NVIDIA often faces high expectations, especially due to its leadership in GPUs, AI, and data centers. When expectations are this high, any disappointment, even if minor, can lead to a significant drop in the stock price. If earnings or guidance fall short of what the market expects, the stock could drop, making a long put profitable. 2. Elevated Valuations NVIDIAs stock has often traded at high valuations relative to its earnings and revenue. If investors start to believe that these valuations are too stretched, especially in the face of any potential slowdown in growth or broader economic concerns, the stock could see a significant decline. A long put would benefit from this scenario. 3. PostEarnings Volatility Even when companies report strong earnings, the market can sometimes react negatively, especially if there are concerns about future growth, increasing costs, or potential competition. With options, you can benefit from the increased volatility that often follows earnings reports. If the stock drops even slightly, a long put could gain value quickly. 4. SectorWide Risks The technology sector, particularly companies like NVIDIA, can be sensitive to broader economic conditions, such as rising interest rates or inflation. If theres a sectorwide downturn or if tech stocks are under pressure due to macroeconomic concerns, NVIDIAs stock could decline, making a long put an attractive play. 5. Risk of Guidance Cuts or Conservative Outlook Even if NVIDIA reports strong current earnings, the company might issue conservative guidance due to uncertainties in the global economy, competition, or potential supply chain issues. The market often reacts negatively to such guidance, which could drive the stock lower and make a long put a winning bet. Therefore I will be inversing OP

Their leadership in the AI chip market, particularly with the A100 and H100 GPUs, positions them well to capture a substantial share of the increasing investments in AI. This trend is likely to continue as AI becomes more integral across industries. 2. Data Center Growth NVIDIAs data center business is a crucial revenue stream, and as AI adoption accelerates, the demand for their GPUs in cloud computing and AI workloads will likely increase. This segment is a critical area to watch, as it could continue to drive NVIDIAs growth beyond Q2. 3. Gaming Sector Resilience Despite challenges in the broader tech sector, NVIDIAs gaming segment remains robust. The gaming markets demand for highperformance GPUs ensures steady revenue, and NVIDIAs strong brand loyalty among gamers helps maintain this segments stability. 4. Strategic Partnerships and Expansions NVIDIAs strategic moves into markets like automotive and edge computing diversify its revenue streams and reduce reliance on any single segment. These expansions also open up new growth avenues, particularly as industries like automotive increasingly adopt AI technologies. 5. Product Innovations NVIDIAs commitment to innovation, particularly in developing GPUs tailored for AI and professional visualization, keeps them ahead of competitors. The ability to command higher average selling prices and maintain strong margins is a testament to their competitive advantage. 6. Supply Chain Management Effective supply chain management has been crucial in an industry where many companies have struggled. NVIDIAs ability to meet high demand while navigating supply chain challenges is a significant competitive edge, ensuring they can capitalize on market opportunities. Regarding your point about current estimates not accounting for operating leverage, this is an insightful observation. If NVIDIA can achieve greater operating leverage as revenue scales, this could lead to higher profitability than currently anticipated, potentially driving the stock into the 140145 range by the end of the year. However, this would also depend on broader market conditions, the continued strength of their core segments, and how well they manage any macroeconomic headwinds. Overall, NVIDIA appears wellpositioned to deliver strong Q2 earnings, and your analysis captures the essential factors that could drive this outcome.

NVIDIAs NVDA Stock Expected to Plummet to 82 Post Q2 Earnings 1. Overestimated AI Chip Demand 2. Data Center Growth Slowing Down 3. Vulnerabilities in the Gaming Sector 5. Product Innovation Fatigue 6. Supply Chain Vulnerabilities

Completely different. In the late 90s and early 2000s, there was little to no oversight on mortgage brokers. Well, the big loan buyers Lehman Brothers amongst many others were offering disastrously dangerous loan products. For example, someone with a 580 credit score could borrower up to 95, cash out, on the value of their home AND state their income! And the cherry on top was that most were adjustable rate loans. Well, that set the stage for 2008 as they were bundling these risky loans into mortgage backed securities MBS that were supposed to be lighter risk. They werent at all. Then the perfect storm hits with 911. Recession, then comes the defaults. On a MASSIVE scale. Those loans, for the most part, are not prevalent in the market these days. This scenario we are in is also a possible perfect storm. Years of robust growth and cheap money got an entire generation spending like it was going to last forever. Here we are now. 8 trillion in debt heavier, the middle class making generally the same amount but inflation out of this world. And when you hear CPI 3 YOY you know better than that. How much did you pay for those groceries in 2019? How about that car? Or services? Now what is actual inflation? Not 3. And those trusted brands you buy....well, you are still buying them.....but getting less for the same price. Stagflation is the word. The corporations are showing record profits. How??? Thats how. Do some research on how we got out of the 2008 recession. It was actually the middle class that didnt really have the money kept spending. THAT group got us out of that one while the big dogs sat on the sideline with huge amounts of cash. They won big then and are winning big now and will win big again if we do slip into an official recession.
Because we had a functional printer back then, we dont now.

The colored gemstone market is complex and opaque. A spot price is unrealistic in a market of such varying qualities. Its not the first time people have tried to corner a gemstone market, most fail, government regulated supply is a weak hold and product moves through with the correct connections and money. Blue Zircon can be found in many localities and white zircon can be treated. The price and comparison should also be measured against a basket of similar gem material which you will find a similar trend in pricing that many mid tier gems have moved up in value over the last several years. This last year in Tucson anecdotal discussions with gem dealers and purchasers indicated some level of inverse pricing from mine to consumers, it was more expensive material at the mine source than what was being sold in Tucson, mainly due to cash buyers paying premiums for large lots at the source. The price to reach 10K per carat is unrealistic in a lifetime term. This material is just not that rare to reach high grade ruby and sapphire pricing. if you can get 300 you are good, if you get 500 for high quality large pieces great, but the average is lower and there is a lot of material that is treated flooding the market some show up directly at the mines. A good resource on pricing and markets is GIA field Gemologist Wim Vertriest who has written many articles on sourcing stones and the market in general and has a large focus in SE Asian markets. Separately if you are looking to have large high quality pieces cut please reach out, I have some experience in faceting

Step 2 Market to internet regards looking for a quick buck. Step 3 Set up crypto shitcoin so these same regards can get in on the action. Step 4 Dump all your shitcoins and profit. Been happening for fuckin centuries not just with crypto. Even happened to an actual gold mine. See the BreX scandal.

Several years ago I stumbled into a weird rock market. A rock called a Saffordite was sought after by extremely eccentric people and considered very rare. Except I found an easy way to find these rocks. With a few friends we went out and mined roughly 500 lbs of these rocks and contacted a guy who sold them. He bought the whole lot from us for around 10k dollars. We went back out and mined another 200 or so lbs but when we reached back out the broker told us hed sold roughly 100 lbs of our first find before the market collapsed. Once there was a steady sales stream the interest and bidding wars for these rocks was gone. To this day saffordites sell for pennies an ounce... Thats how we single handedly crashed a rock market.

Story time I have a friend whose dad is a gem and mineral dealer. When we were in high school it wasnt his full time job or anything, it was more of a hobbyside business. But then after he retired it basically becalmed his full time jobbusiness. And let me tell you, business is booming. Ive seen some wild things while traveling in that circle of high end gem and mineral dealing. In Colorado for example, where weed is legal but the banks wont touch it, Ive seen people come in and drop 30k, 50k etc. in cash on a single tourmaline, with the intent to resell it at some point as a way to legitimize their capital. We call them Wookiees because theyre typically very hairy, and dont bathe much. Then theres the oil and gas geologists who have absurd amounts of money but dress like theyre in between hikes. Theres the HealyFealys who believe the crystals have some sort of magical properties. How they pick a rock thatll increase their Luck, or Prosperity, or bolster their love life is anyones guess. Then youve got the standard investors who are looking to diversify their wealth into collectible class assets or Asset Class Collectibles Ive heard both used. Theyre looking for something they can park their money in and resell for a profit later. You also get just collectors. People whose rock collection went way beyond what you could even fathom as a kid picking cool rocks out of a garden bed. Ive seen some specimens change hands for 7 figures or more. Truly a different world.

Hmmm. Blue zircon has a similar hardness to emerald, quartz and garnet. Fair to tough range. A lot of people say dont recommend emerald for a daily wear ring or engagement ring as can get scratched and damaged. So ..it is more preferred corundum stones and diamond for that. There are also a lot of advancements in synthetic diamonds happening now first mostly yellow, but also blue diamonds might be created. Sapphire the most famous blue stone can already be created synthetically and blue topaz as well is relatively affordable just from natural sources and a fair amount of good color tanzanite floating around. There are some that like collecting niche gemstones but that is a small part of the market compared to the jewelry industry. The name..is also a problem in that it has nothing to do with cubic zirconia, but the name zircon sounds similar so peoples perception it is a synthetic or low cost gemstone. But one of its biggest flaws in use in jewelry is that exposure to UV can turn blue zircon into an unappealing brown. That is the main reason it has not been widely adopted for jewelry. Almost a similar problem to welo opal that turns dull and yellow over time. Apatite...another blue stone that has a lovely shade can also fade and change color with UV exposure.

Most of what OP said is of course complete bullshit. Blue zircons are not the oldest gems on earth. Zircons in general, because of their small Uranium content, are used in Geology to date the rocks they are in using the UPb dating method. So they found some inherited small zircons in an Australian conglomerate that were 4.4 Ga years old. those are neither blue though nor do they have anything to do with OPs zircons. OPs zircons are less than 1 million year old and therefore very young certainly much much younger than any diamonds. In fact, you would never find natural i.e. not heat treated old, gemquality zircons. The radioactive elements in them mainly U and Th decay over time and slowly destroy the crystal lattice. All old zircons will therefore look somewhat eaten up. Blue Zircons are also neither rare nor even natural. The blue color is achieved by heating gemquality zircons which are usually yellow or orange up to about 1000degC. Zircons themselves are not rare at all either, almost every rock has some in them. Even large gemquality specimens are relatively common. Thats why you can get them for literally pennies on the internet.

Im a geologist and this is the most hilarious thing I have read on here in a while. Its not undervalued, it is valued at what the market is willing to pay for it and their plan to artificially drive up demand is laughably unhinged to anyone who understands anything about anything. OP makes it sound like theres only one closed mine in Cambodia, but their own country, Australia, produces like 40 of the worlds supply of blue zircon and its also mined in Sri Lanka and Africa, as well. Zircon itself is a very common mineral, like its everywhere in the Earths crust. Its also a terrible gemstone due to its brittleness and tendency to scratch. Weve also been able to grow and mass produce zirconscubic zirconia in a laboratory setting, which requires no slave labor, for decades now, and its becoming cheaper and more efficient year after year. There are also multiple other gemstones with similar visual qualities that are much more suitable for jewelry applications and are much cheaper, like moissanite and blue topaz. The extra stupid part of this is that there are plenty of gemstonesminerals which actually have the increasing scarcity that OP is looking for. Turquoise is a great example. It is a relatively rare semiprecious gemstone with only a handful of mines producing it in any significant quantity worldwide. Most of what you see labeled as turquoise on the market now is actually cheaper and more common stones marketed as turquoise because of how scarce real turquoise is becoming. Its basically only found in great quantities in the American southwest and the mines in the southwest have been running dry and falling short of demand for quite a while. In conclusion, I have a bachelors degree in why OP is dumb soon to be a masters!.

Zircon from Ratanakiri Province, northeastern Cambodia, is well known in the gem trade for its vivid blue colour that results from heat treatment. The untreated brown material turns blue under reducing conditions at 9001,000degC. Ratanakiri zircon is characterised by remarkably low contents of trace elements. Both of your comments are not entirely correct. If you own 100 shares you can sell a covered call, but if you want to sell covered puts you need to short the stock, because the buyer of the put has the right to sell shares to you, meaning you have to buy their shares. You can only cover this with a short position since when you short a stock you borrow and sell it first and buy it later and give back the borrowed shares. You mentioned that if you sell a call and the buyer of the call exercises the call, you give away your shares for nothing. That is not true and Im curious where you got that info from honest question. When you write a call the buyer of the call has the right to buy 100 shares from you at the strike price. That means that if the buyer exercises his right, you have to sell 100 shares in exchange for the strike price. In other words, if the strike price is 30 and the buyer exercises the call, you sell him your 100 shares for 100 x 30 3,000.

DEVIN is not replacing software devs anytime soon but more of the realization that a small team of good devs are way better than an army of mediocre ones, and companies can get away or even do more with less people The previous decade of push has pushed more people into IT than what is truly required by the industry

Not sure I agree, declining IT jobs in US might suggest a broader downtrend not that AI is replacing people. Chinese AI is further advanced working robotaxis in multiple cities and weve not seen huge ROIs. Instead weve seen Tesla moon even though theyve consistently failed to deliver and are now working with Baidu to develop robotaxis. All this suggests a fair bit of speculation though admittedly Tesla is an outlier in mag 7

I was an AI engineer until recently. The issue for corporate America is they dont really understand it. They fake demos then become disinterested in their fake results. However, it doesnt matter, it will be adopted not because but despite management. It will be integrated into the products they buy and they will be unable to escape it. It will indeed replace a lot of jobs. It would have no value if it didnt. What generative AI does well today is unsupervised categorization, text and image creation, and as an ai coding pair. The job losses will be more severe in future years.

GenAI wasnt on peoples radars just a few years ago but businesses are sparing no expense to integrate it in a few years. And make no mistake, a lot of people can and will be displaced. Im not talking about mom and pops bagel shop down the street, Im talking about the needle movers. People who think its some sort of fad have no clue what it is and all the ways it can be used, yet alone have used it before.
It will start with IT, as it was born in IT, but AI is going to impact pretty much every sector of the economy. Hype or not, if there is money to be saved, it will.
So, puts it is then
There will be no long term. Ai is life, until ai is death.
Im bearish on the current capabilities of AI, but this post connects some dots in a highly regarded way, thus Ill upvote it.

Try multimedia design. AI is laying the field to waste. Silicon valley gunning for the jobs people actually want to do.

The code that AI produces are basic at best, abysmal most of the time with the current models. DEVIN is not replacing software devs anytime soon AI isnt all or nothing. It doesnt have to autonomously create 100 of the code in order to be incredibly useful, increase the efficiency of devs, and decrease the number of devs it takes to do the same amount of work. Thats a red herring.

If its just part of a broader downtrend, then why is IT disproportionately affected? The sector leads unemployment stats. What Im suggesting is that in the first wave of adoption of AI, the jobs data is exactly what wed expect to see. Employment trended up in fields unlikely to be directly affected by AI, like healthcare and construction, and big tech is where wed expect to see early efficiency gains and increased unemployment the gig economy is being massively disrupted as well, which is what wed expect. Instead of expecting AI to double earnings estimates with cartoonish ROI, which is what a lot of people apparently expected and now theyre yammering about the bubble bursting, what wed probably realistically expect to see is what were seeing continued respectable growth and earnings but with fewer IT workers. There are other explanations that fit the data, but what Im saying is that the data fits this explanation.
